revision.comment: +[[Category:16th-century geographers]]; +[[Category:16th-century German mathematicians]]; +[[Category:16th-century German writers]] using [[WP:HC|HotCat]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} [[File:Johannes Schoner Astronomer 01.jpg|thumb|200px|Joan Schonerus Mathematicus]]
'''Johannes Schöner''' (16 January 1477 in [[Karlstadt am Main]] – 16 January 1547 in [[Nürnberg]]) (aka, Johann Schönner, Johann Schoener, Jean Schönner, Joan Schoenerus) was a renowned and respected [[Germany|German]] [[polymath]]. It is best to refer to him using the usual 16th-century Latin term "mathematicus", as the areas of study to which he devoted his life were very different from those now considered to be the domain of the mathematician. He was a [[priest]], [[astronomer]], [[astrologer]], [[geographer]], [[cosmographer]], [[cartographer]], [[mathematician]], [[globe]] and [[scientific instrument]] maker and editor and publisher of scientific tests. In his own time he enjoyed a European wide reputation as an innovative and influential globe maker and cosmographer and as one of the continent's leading and most authoritative astrologers.<ref>Norbert Holst, ''Mundus, Mirabilia, Mentalität: Weltbild und Quellen des Kartographen Johannes Schöner: eine Spurensuche,'' Frankfurt/Oder, Scripvaz, 1999. {{ISBN|3-931278-10-7}}; John W. Hessler , ''A Renaissance Globemaker's Toolbox: Johannes Schöner and the Revolution of Modern Science, 1475-1550,'' Washington, DC: Library of Congress; London: In association with D. Giles Ltd., 2013. {{ISBN|9781907804168}}</ref> Today he is remembered as an influential pioneer in the history of globe making and as a man who played a significant role in the events that led up to the publishing of [[Nicolaus Copernicus|Copernicus']] "[[De revolutionibus]]" in [[Nürnberg]] in 1543.
==Life==
===Early life===
Schöner was born on 16 January 1477 in [[Karlstadt am Main]] in [[Lower Franconia]]. As with most Renaissance scholars nothing is known about his parents or his early life. All that is known is that he had a brother, Peter, to whom he addressed his "Arzneibuch" in 1528. Quite detailed information for Schöner’s adult life, at least up to 1506, has been preserved in his own marginalia in his copy of [[Regiomontanus]]' printed [[Ephemerides]], which he used as a diary. He matriculated at the [[University of Erfurt]] in the winter semester 1494/5 and graduated Baccalaureus on 21 March 1498. He was appointed to a position in the school in [[Gemünden am Main|Gemünden]] on 22 February 1499 and ordained as a Catholic priest in the [[Bishopric of Bamberg]] on 13 June 1500. On 2 February 1500 he moved to [[Bamberg]] and was appointed chaplain in [[Hallstatt]] near Bamberg on 18 April 1500. His next appointment was as vicar in his hometown Karlstadt from 4 June 1504. Between 4 May and 29 October 1506 he was again in Bamberg before he returned to Karlstadt. His diary also informs us that he entered a relationship with Kunigunde Holocher in 1499, with whom he had three children: a son Johannes born on 1 February 1502, a daughter Sibilla born on 12 June 1503 and a second son Vitus born on 21 November 1504.
[[File:LoC Treasures Gallery Waldseemüller map display 2007.jpg|thumb|200px|A facsimile copy of Schöner's Waldseemüller map at the [[Library of Congress]] in Washington]] Schöner was the owner of the only specimen of the 1507 [[Waldseemüller map]] of the world that has survived and which was rediscovered at [[Schloss Wolfegg]] in [[Upper Swabia]] in 1901. Since 2003 it is in possession of the [[Library of Congress]].<ref name="LibCon">{{Cite news| url=https://www.loc.gov/today/pr/2003/03-110.html|title=News from the Library of Congress: Library of Congress Completes Purchase of Waldseemüller Map|publisher=[[Library of Congress]]|date=18 June 2003 |accessdate=1 May 2014}}</ref>
===Bamberg=== [[Image:Schöner - Algorithmus demonstratus, 1534 - 144343.jpg|thumb|''Algorithmus demonstratus'', 1534]]
No diary exists after 1506, and up to 1515 there are only indirect traces of Schöner's existence in the financial records of the bishopric and in the correspondence of Lorenz Beheim (?1457 - 1521), who after 24 years in Rome as chamberlain to Pope Alexander IV had returned to Bamberg in 1505 as a canon of the cathedral.
1526, he was called to Nürnberg as the first professor of mathematics at the newly founded gymnasium ''Aegidianum'', a post he held till one year prior to his death. At the same time, he converted to Protestantism and married.
Already in Bamberg, he owned his own printing company and published many [[map]]s and [[globe]]s. The very first printed globe of the sky was made in his workshop in 1515. He made another [[globe]] in 1520.[[File:Schöner globe 1520 western hemisphere.jpg|thumb|Western hemisphere of the Schöner globe from 1520.]]
Schöner had also made still unpublished data of [[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]] observations from Walther available to Copernicus, 45 observations in total, 14 of them with longitude and latitude. Copernicus used three of them in "[[De revolutionibus]]", giving only longitudes, and falsely attributing them to Schöner. The values differed slightly from the ones published by Schöner in 1544.
1538, [[Georg Joachim Rheticus]], a young professor of mathematics at [[Wittenberg]] and former assistant of Copernicus, stayed for some time with Schöner who convinced him to visit [[Nicolaus Copernicus]] in [[Frombork|Frauenburg]]. In 1540, Rheticus dedicated the first published report of Copernicus work, the ''[[Narratio prima]]'', to Schöner, to test the waters of the reaction by the [[Catholic Church]]. As this was well received, Copernicus finally agreed to publish his main work, and Rheticus prepared Copernicus' manuscript for printing.
In Nürnberg, Schöner published in 1544 the astronomical observations of [[Regiomontanus]] and Walther, as well as manuscripts of Regiomontanus, which had been in the hand of Walther, as ''Observationes XXX annorum a I. Regiomontano et B. Walthero Norimbergae habitae, [4°, Norimb. 1544].''
A [[Impact crater|crater]] on [[Mars]] is named in his honor.
==See also== {{commons category|Johannes Schoner}} *[[Johannes Schöner globe]] *[[Ancient world maps]] *[[World map]]
== References == {{Reflist}} ==External links== From the [https://www.loc.gov/rr/rarebook/rosenwald.html Lessing J. Rosenwald Collection] at the [[Library of Congress]]: *[http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.rbc/General.75583 ''Joannis Schoneri Carolostadii Opusculum Astrologicum''] *[http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.rbc/Rosenwald.0692 ''Opera mathematica Ioannis Schoneri in vnvm volvmen congesta ...''] *[http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.rbc/rosenwald.0628 Luculentissima quaedam terrae totius descriptio]. [https://books.google.com.au/books?id=avZu4BiPmDgC&pg=PT140&lpg=PT140&dq=Brori+Luculentissima&source=bl&ots=nnfy_-555W&sig=_KIAPPe-O0MOoecDQSN89loJsyg&hl=en&sa=X&ei=M-KRVYbhHMa5mwWPj4LICg&ved=0CCcQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=Brori%20Luculentissima&f=false also at:] *[http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.rbc/General.75583 Carolostadii Opusculum astrologicum] (1539 copy). From the Rare Book and Special Collection Division at the [[Library of Congress]]

page.title: List of Latin place names in Africa

revision.text:
{{Latin place names}} This list includes [[Africa]]n [[countries]] and [[regions]] that were part of the [[Roman Empire]], or that were given [[Latin]] place names in [[historical]] [[Reference work|references]].
==Background== [[Image:Africae romanae Urbes.jpg|left|thumb|250px|Roman places in Africa]] Until the [[Modern Era]], [[Latin]] was the [[Lingua franca|common language]] for [[scholarship]] and [[Cartography|mapmaking]]. During the 19th and 20th centuries, [[Germany|German]] scholars in particular have made significant contributions to the study of historical place names, or ''Ortsnamenkunde''. These studies have, in turn, contributed to the study of [[genealogy]]. For genealogists and historians of pre-Modern Europe, knowing alternate names of places is vital to extracting information from both public and private records. Even specialists in this field point out, however, that the information can be easily taken out of context, since there is a great deal of repetition of place names throughout Europe; reliance purely on apparent connections should therefore be tempered with valid historical methodology.
==Caveats and notes== Latin place names are not always exclusive to one place — for example, there were several Roman cities whose names began with ''Colonia'' and then a more descriptive term. During the [[Middle Ages]], these were often shortened to just ''Colonia''. One of these, ''Colonia Agrippinensis'', retains the name today in the form of [[Cologne]].
Early sources for [[ancient Rome|Roman]] names show numerous variants and spellings of the [[Latin]] names.
The modern canonical name is listed first. Sources are listed chronologically. In general, only the earliest source is shown for each name, although many of the names are recorded in more than one of the sources. Where the source differs in spelling, or has other alternatives, these are listed following the source. As an aid to searching, variants are spelled completely, and listed in most likely chronology.
Superscripts indicate: # Latinized form of the Greek-derived name. # Latinized form of the Asian-derived name via Greek. # Altered Latinized form of the Greek-derived name.
==Cities and towns in [[Algeria]]==
{| border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3" ! Canonical Latin Name (source(s): variant(s)) !! English Name (native language(s)) - older name(s), (other language(s)), location(s) |- |[[Castellum Dimmidi]]|| [[Messaad]] |- |[[Cuicul]]|| [[Djemila]] |- | [[Hippo Regius]] or Hippone (French)|| [[Annaba]] or Bône (French) |- |Vescera ||[[Biskra]] |- | [[Cirta]]|| [[Constantine, Algeria|Constantine]] |- | [[Chullu]]|| [[Collo]] (wilaya Skikda) |- | [[Rusicade]]|| [[Skikda]] |- | [[Milevum]]|| [[Mila, Algeria|Mila]] |- | [[Mascula]]|| [[Khenchela]] |}

==Cities and towns in [[Tunisia]]==
{| border="1" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3" ! Canonical Latin Name (source(s): variant(s)) !! English Name (native language(s)) - older name(s), (other language(s)), location(s) |- |[[Bulla Regia]]||near [[Jendouba]] |- |Carthago|| [[Carthage]], near [[Tunis]] |- |[[Hadrumetum]] ||[[Sousse]] |- |[[Leptis Parva]], Leptis Minor, Leptiminus||[[Lamta]] - south west of [[Sousse]] |- |Municipum Julium Uticense|| older name: [[Utica, Tunisia|Utica]] - north west of [[Carthage]], near [[Tunis]] |- |Mustis|| El Krib |- |[[Sbeitla|Sufetula]]||[[Sbeïtla]] |- | [[Thuburbo Majus]]|| near Zagouhan |- |[[Thysdrus]] ||[[El Jem]] |}
== See also == * [[Chemical elements named after places]] (several element names employ Latin place names)
==References== In order of likely publication:
*'''PNH''': [[Pliny the Elder|Pliny]] (Gaius Plinius Secundus), ''[[Pliny's Natural History|Naturalis Historia]]''; book "PNH" chapter (that is, "37PNH81" instead of the usual "N.H.xxxvii.81"). *'''PG''': [[Ptolemy]] (Claudius Ptolemaeus), ''[[Ptolemy#Geography|Geographia]]''; book "PG" chapter (that is, "2PG3" instead of the usual "II.3"). Ptolemy wrote in [[Greek language|Greek]], so names are [[transliteration|transliterated]] back into [[Latin]] to reveal the original form. *'''HLU''': [[Hofmann, Johann Jacob]] (1635-1706): ''Lexicon Universale'' *'''GOL''': The standard reference to Latin placenames, with their modern equivalents, is [[Johann Georg Theodor Grässe|Dr. J. G. Th. Grässe]], ''[[Orbis Latinus|Orbis Latinus: Lexikon lateinischer geographischer Namen des Mittelalters und der Neuzeit]]'' (1861), an exhaustive work of meticulous German scholarship that is available online in the second edition of 1909. To use it, one must understand German names of countries, as they were in 1909. The original was re-edited and expanded in a multivolume edition in 1972.
== External links == *[http://www.bayerische-landesbibliothek-online.de/orbis-latinus Grässe, Orbis Latinus] *[http://www.columbia.edu/acis/ets/Graesse/contents.html Grässe, Orbis Latinus] *[http://www.uni-mannheim.de/mateo/camenaref/hofmann.html Hofmann: Lexicon Universale] *[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Roman/Texts/Pliny_the_Elder/home.html Pliny the Elder: the Natural History] *[http://penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Gazetteer/Periods/Roman/_Texts/Ptolemy/home.html Ptolemy: the Geography] *[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/183/ Unesco: Leptis Magna] *[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/836/ Unesco: Volubilis] *[http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/191/ Unesco: Cuicul] {{Place name etymologies}} [[Category:Names of places in Africa]] [[Category:Lists of Latin place names|Africa]] [[Category:Lists of cities by toponymy|Latin, Africa]] [[Category:Africa-related lists|Latin place names]]

{{Politics of Ethiopia}} This is a '''list of [[President of Ethiopia|Presidents]] of [[Ethiopia]]''' and also a list of '''heads of state''' after the fall of the [[Ethiopian Empire]] in 1974. Until 1974, the heads of state of the Ethiopian Empire were either [[Emperor of Ethiopia|Emperors]] or regents. From the [[coup d'état]] of the [[Derg]] leading to the fall of the Empire in September 1974 until March 1975, the Derg considered the Crown Prince [[Asfaw Wossen]] as the nominal ''head of state'' – which the Crown Prince refused to accept. During this time, the ''Chairmen of the Derg'', the leaders of the Derg, were to be considered as ''acting heads of state''. After 21 March 1975, the ''Derg military junta'' fully took over. Until the establishment of the [[People's Democratic Republic of Ethiopia]] in 1987, still dominated by Derg figures, Chairmen of the Derg have to be considered ''heads of state'' – but not ''presidents''. After the fall of the Derg and the establishment of the [[Transitional Government of Ethiopia]] in 1991, the first immediate President ([[Meles Zenawi]]) has to be considered an ''Interim President''. Since the formal establishment of the office of President in 1987, there have been 6 official presidents. The President is the [[head of state]] of Ethiopia. The current president is [[Sahle-Work Zewde]], who is also the first female president of Ethiopia, [[Ethiopian presidential election, 2018|elected]] on 25 October 2018 by members of the [[Federal Parliamentary Assembly]]. ==List== In the list, the ''Chairmen of the Derg'' are considered to be ''heads of state'' – but are not considered to be President. Consequently, the numbering starts with the first establishment of the office of the ''President of Ethiopia'' in 1987. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" ! colspan=2|Name ! Portrait ! Birth–Death ! Elected ! Took office ! Left office ! Political party

page.title: List of Prince Edward Island by-elections

revision.comment: v1.43 - Repaired 1 link to disambiguation page - [[WP:DPL|(You can help)]] - [[Patrick Blake]]
revision.text:
The list of Prince Edward Island by-elections includes every by-election held in the Canadian province of Prince Edward Island since 1873. By-elections occur whenever there is a vacancy in the [[Prince Edward Island Legislative Assembly|Legislative Assembly]], although an imminent general election may allow the vacancy to remain until the dissolution of parliament. Until 1932 incumbent members were required to recontest their seats upon being appointed to Cabinet. These Ministerial by-elections were almost always uncontested. ==65th General Assembly of Prince Edward Island 2015-present== {|class=wikitable style="width:100%" !By-election !! Date !! page.title: List of countries without armed forces

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/199.193.117.44|199.193.117.44]] ([[User talk:199.193.117.44|talk]]) to last version by Shellwood
revision.text:
{{short description|Wikimedia list article}} [[File:Map of countries without armed forces.svg|thumb|right|350px|Countries without regular military forces {{legend|#47828f|States with no military forces}} {{legend|#5f8f47|States with no standing army, but with limited military forces}} ]]
This is a '''list of countries without armed forces'''. The term ''country'' here means [[sovereign state]]s and not [[List of dependent territories|dependencies]] (e.g., [[Guam]], [[Northern Mariana Islands]], [[Bermuda]]), whose defense is the responsibility of another country or an army alternative. The term ''[[armed forces]]'' refers to any government-sponsored defense used to further the [[Domestic policy|domestic]] and [[Foreign policy|foreign]] policies of their respective government. Some of the countries listed, such as [[Iceland]] and [[Monaco]], have no [[standing armies]] but still have a non-police military force.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mfa.is/foreign-policy/security/the-defence-act/ |title=The Defence Act | Defence and Security Affairs | Subjects | Ministry for Foreign Affairs |publisher=Mfa.is |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gouv.mc/Gouvernement-et-Institutions/Le-Gouvernement/Departement-de-l-Interieur/Direction-de-la-Surete-Publique |title=Direction de la Sûreté Publique / Département de l'Intérieur / Le Gouvernement / Gouvernement et Institutions / Portail du Gouvernement - Monaco |language=fr |publisher=Gouv.mc |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/faculty/rwinslow/europe/monaco.html |title=Comparative Criminology | Europe - Monaco |publisher=Rohan.sdsu.edu |date=2002-01-01 |accessdate=2012-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120430001200/http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/faculty/rwinslow/europe/monaco.html |archivedate=2012-04-30 |df= }}</ref>
Many of the twenty-one countries listed here typically have had a long-standing agreement with a former [[Military occupation|occupying country]]; one example is the agreement between [[Monaco]] and [[France]], which has [[History of Monaco|existed for at least 300 years]].<ref name="monaco"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/mn.html |title=CIA - The World Factbook |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> The [[Compact of Free Association]] nations of the [[Marshall Islands]], [[Federated States of Micronesia]] (FSM), and [[Palau]] rely on the United States for their defense. They ensure their national security concerns are addressed through annual Joint Committee Meetings to discuss defense matters with [[United States Indo-Pacific Command|US Pacific Command]]. [[Andorra]] has a [[Military of Andorra|small army]], and can request defensive aid if necessary,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boe.es/buscar/doc.php?coleccion=iberlex&id=1993/16868 |title=Documento BOE-A-1993-16868 |publisher=BOE.es |date=1993-06-30 |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref name="andorra">{{cite web|url=http://www.theodora.com/wfb1990/andorra/andorra_military.html|title=Andorra Defense Forces - 1990|accessdate=2008-02-27|year=1990|publisher=CIA World Factbook}}</ref> while [[Iceland]] had a [[Iceland Defense Force|unique agreement]] with the [[United States]] that lasted until 2006, which required them to provide defense to Iceland when needed.<ref name="iceland"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://usmilitary.about.com/od/assignments/a/iceland.htm |title=U.S. Military Forces Leaving Iceland |publisher=Usmilitary.about.com |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref>
The remaining countries are responsible for their own defense, and operate either without any armed forces, or with limited armed forces. Some of the countries, such as [[Costa Rica]] and [[Grenada]], underwent a process of [[demilitarization]].<ref name="rss">{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27|url=https://www.state.gov/p/wha/rls/70686.htm|title=Treaty Establishing the Regional Security System (1996) |publisher=United States Department of State }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1990-03-17/news/mn-183_1_palace-guard |title=Breakup of Palace Guard Helps to Demilitarize Haiti - Los Angeles Times |publisher=Articles.latimes.com |date=1990-03-17 |accessdate=2012-06-17 |first=Don A. |last=Schanche}}</ref><ref name="costa rica"/> Other countries were formed without armed forces, such as [[History of Samoa|Samoa over {{round|{{age|format=raw|1962|1|1}}|-1}} years ago]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toptenz.net/top-10-countries-without-military-forces.php |title=Top 10 Countries Without Military Forces | Top 10 Lists |publisher=TopTenz.net |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> the primary reason being that they were, or still are, under protection from another nation at their point of independence. All of the countries on this list are considered to be in a situation of "non-militarization."<ref name="non-military">{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27 |url=http://www.demilitarisation.org/Countrieswithoutarmy.htm |title=Non-militarization |publisher=Demilitarization |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071225042431/http://www.demilitarisation.org/Countrieswithoutarmy.htm |archivedate=December 25, 2007 }}</ref>
[[Haiti]] abolished its army in 1994, after a US [[Operation Uphold Democracy|invasion]] deposed the military junta which had ruled the country since 1992. In 2017, after the end of the [[MINUSTAH]], the Haitian government announced the restoration of the [[Haitian Armed Forces]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-haiti-military/haitian-army-set-to-make-controversial-return-after-two-decades-idUSKBN1DJ01M|title=Haitian army set to make controversial return after two decades|first=Reuters|last=Editorial|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/haiti-revived-military/4117695.html|title=Haiti Hasn't Had a Military in Years — It Does Now|first=Yvan Martin|last=Jasmin|publisher=}}</ref>
== Countries without armed forces == {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" |- |+Countries with no official military forces |- !scope=col| Country !scope=col| Comments !scope=col| Ref(s) |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Andorra}} |Andorra has no standing army but signed treaties with Spain and France for its protection. Its small volunteer [[Military of Andorra|army]] is purely ceremonial in function. The paramilitary [[Andorra#GIPA|GIPA]] (trained in counter-terrorism and hostage management) is part of the [[Police Corps of Andorra|national police]]. Defense assistance is provided by [[France]] and [[Spain]] under an informal agreement between the three countries. | align=center|<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/an.html |title=CIA - The World Factbook |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://turisme.andorralavella.ad/?q=en/node/281 |title=El Sometent | Tourism |publisher=Turisme.andorralavella.ad |date=2011-05-17 |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Dominica}} |Dominica has not had a [[Military of Dominica|standing army]] since 1981. Defense is the responsibility of the [[Regional Security System]]. | align=center|<ref name="Dominica">{{cite web|accessdate=2015-07-07|url=http://www.demilitarisation.org/spip.php?article51&lang=en|title=Overview. 26 countries without armies|publisher=APRED}}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Grenada}} | Has not had a [[Military of Grenada|standing army]] since 1983, after the [[Invasion of Grenada|American-led invasion]]. The [[Royal Grenada Police Force]] maintains a paramilitary special service unit for internal security purposes. Defense is the responsibility of the [[Regional Security System]]. |align=center|<ref name="rss"/> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Kiribati}} | Under the Constitution the [[Military of Kiribati|only forces permitted]] are the [[Law enforcement in Kiribati|police]], which includes a [[Military of Kiribati|Maritime Surveillance Unit]] for internal security. The Maritime Surveillance is equipped with small arms, and maintains one [[Pacific class patrol boat|''Pacific''-class patrol boat]], the ''Teanoai''. Defense assistance is provided by [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]] under an informal agreement between the three countries. |align=center|<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27|url=http://www.theodora.com/wfb1991/kiribati/kiribati_military.html|title=Kiribati Defense Forces - 1991 |publisher=CIA World Factbook }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2011/kiribati |title=Kiribati |publisher=Freedom House |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=Australian Government, Department of Defence |url=http://www.defence.gov.au/opEx/global/opkiribatiassist/index.htm |title=Operation KIRIBATI ASSIST - Department of Defence |publisher=Defence.gov.au |date=1943-11-20 |accessdate=2012-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120502084810/http://www.defence.gov.au/opEx/global/opkiribatiassist/index.htm |archivedate=2012-05-02 |df= }}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Liechtenstein}} | Abolished [[Military of Liechtenstein|its army]] in 1868 because it was deemed too costly. An army is only permitted in times of war, but that situation has never occurred. Liechtenstein maintains a [[Law enforcement in Liechtenstein|police force]] with a [[police tactical unit]], equipped with small arms to carry out internal security duties. Defense assistance is provided by [[Austria]] and [[Switzerland]] under an informal agreement among the three countries. |align=center|<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/9403.htm|title=Background Note: Liechtenstein |publisher=United States Department of State }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.landespolizei.li/Portals/0/docs/pdf-Files/Imagebroschuere_LP_e_end.pdf |title=Imagebroschuere_LP_e.indd |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2012-10-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130516220753/http://www.landespolizei.li/Portals/0/docs/pdf-Files/Imagebroschuere_LP_e_end.pdf |archivedate=2013-05-16 |df= }}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Marshall Islands}} | Since the country's foundation the [[Military of the Marshall Islands|only forces permitted]] are the [[Law enforcement in the Marshall Islands|police]], which includes a [[Military of the Marshall Islands|Maritime Surveillance Unit]] for internal security. The Maritime Surveillance Unit is equipped with small arms, and maintains one [[Pacific class patrol boat|''Pacific''-class patrol boat]], the ''Lomor''. Under the [[Compact of Free Association]], defense is the responsibility of the [[United States]]. |align=center|<ref name="marshall islands">{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/26551.htm|title=Background Note: Marshall Islands |publisher=United States Department of State }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2010/marshall-islands|title=Marshall Islands|website=www.freedomhouse.org}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.toptenz.net/top-10-countries-without-military-forces.php |title=Top 10 Countries Without Military Forces | Top 10 Lists |publisher=TopTenz.net |date= |accessdate=2013-03-30}}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flag|Federated States of Micronesia}} | Since the country's foundation [[Military of the Federated States of Micronesia|no military]] has been formed. The only forces permitted are the [[Law enforcement in the Federated States of Micronesia|police]], which maintain a [[Military of the Federated States of Micronesia|Maritime Surveillance Unit]] for internal security. The Maritime Surveillance is equipped with small arms, and maintains three [[Pacific class patrol boat|''Pacific''-class patrol boats]], ''FSS Palikir'', ''FSS Micronesia'', and ''FSS Independence''. Defense is the responsibility of the [[United States]] under the [[Compact of Free Association]]. |align=center|<ref name="micronesia">{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27|url=http://oig.state.gov/oig/lbry/isprpts/eap/11982.htm|title=Inspection of Embassy Kolonia, Federated States of Micronesia (ISP-I-02-09)|publisher=United States Department of State|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070829054355/http://oig.state.gov/oig/lbry/isprpts/eap/11982.htm|archivedate=2007-08-29|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/fm.html |title=CIA - The World Factbook |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2013-03-30}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2011/micronesia|title=Micronesia|website=www.freedomhouse.org}}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Nauru}} | [[Australia]] is responsible for Nauru's defense under an informal agreement between the two countries. However, there is a relatively large armed [[Military of Nauru|police force]], and an auxiliary police force for internal security. |align=center|<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-09-21 |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/nr.html |title=Nauru |publisher=The World Factbook |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080917160201/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/nr.html |archivedate=2008-09-17 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gunpolicy.org/firearms/region/nauru |title=Guns in Nauru: Facts, Figures and Firearm Law |publisher=Gunpolicy.org |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/nr.html |title=CIA - The World Factbook |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504033651/https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/nr.html |archivedate=2012-05-04 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/faculty/rwinslow/asia_pacific/nauru.html |title=Comparative Criminology | Asia - Nauru |publisher=Rohan.sdsu.edu |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151121035025/http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/faculty/rwinslow/asia_pacific/nauru.html |archivedate=2015-11-21 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2011/nauru |title=Nauru |publisher=Freedom House |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Palau}} | Since the country's foundation the [[Military of Palau|only forces permitted]] are the [[Law enforcement in Palau|police]], which includes a 30-person [[Military of Palau|Maritime Surveillance Unit]] for internal security. The Maritime Surveillance is equipped with small arms, and maintains one [[Pacific class patrol boat|''Pacific''-class patrol boat]], ''Remeliik'', and one Japanese granted patrol boat, ''Kedam''. Defense assistance is provided by the [[United States]] under the [[Compact of Free Association]]. |align=center|<ref name="palau">{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27|url=http://www.nationsencyclopedia.com/Asia-and-Oceania/Palau.html|title=PALAU |publisher=Encyclopedia of the Nations }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2011/palau |title=Palau |publisher=Freedom House |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/1840.htm |title=Palau |publisher=State.gov |date=2012-02-07 |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Saint Lucia}} | The [[Royal Saint Lucia Police]] maintain two small paramilitary forces consisting of 116 people, the [[Military of Saint Lucia|Special Service Unit]], and the [[Military of Saint Lucia|Coast Guard]], both units are responsible for internal security. Defense is the responsibility of [[Regional Security System]]. |align=center|<ref name="rss"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rslpf.com/hist.htm |title=Royal Saint Lucia Police Force |publisher=Rslpf.com |date=1961-11-04 |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationmaster.com/country/st-saint-lucia/mil-military |title=Saint Lucian Military statistics, definitions and sources |publisher=Nationmaster.com |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Saint Vincent and the Grenadines}} | The [[Royal Saint Vincent and the Grenadines Police Force]] maintain two small paramilitary forces consisting of 94 people, called the [[Military of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines|Special Service Unit]], and the [[Military of Saint Vincent and the Grenadines|Coast Guard]], both units are responsible for internal security purposes. All Coastguard Commanders with the exception of Lieutenant Commander David Robin have been officers from the [[Royal Navy]]. Defense is the responsibility of [[Regional Security System]]. |align=center|<ref name="rss"/><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/faculty/rwinslow/namerica/stvincentgrenadines.html |title=Comparative Criminology | North America - Saint Vincent and the Grenadines |publisher=Rohan.sdsu.edu |date=1979-10-27 |accessdate=2012-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150622061703/http://www-rohan.sdsu.edu/faculty/rwinslow/namerica/stvincentgrenadines.html |archivedate=2015-06-22 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.security.gov.vc/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=42&Itemid=51 |title=History |publisher=Security.gov.vc |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130325223917/http://www.security.gov.vc/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=42&Itemid=51 |archivedate=2013-03-25 |df= }}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Samoa}} | Since the country's foundation [[Military of Samoa|no military]] has been formed; however, there is a small [[Law enforcement in Samoa|police force]], and a [[Military of Samoa|Maritime Surveillance Unit]] for internal security. The Maritime Surveillance Unit is equipped with small arms, and maintains one [[Pacific class patrol boat|''Pacific''-class patrol boat]], the ''Nafanua''. In accordance to a 1962 Treaty of Friendship, [[New Zealand]] is responsible for defense. |align=center|<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/ws.html|title=Samoa |publisher=The World Factbook}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/1842.htm |title=Samoa |publisher=State.gov |date=2012-02-01 |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2011/samoa |title=Samoa |publisher=Freedom House |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Solomon Islands}} | Maintained a [[Military of Solomon Islands|paramilitary force]] until a heavy ethnic conflict, in which [[RAMSI|Australia, New Zealand and other Pacific countries]] intervened to restore law and order. Since then no military has been maintained, however, there is a relatively large [[Law enforcement in the Solomon Islands|police force]], and a [[Military of Solomon Islands|Maritime Surveillance Unit]] for internal security. The Maritime Surveillance Unit is equipped with small arms, and maintains two [[Pacific class patrol boat|''Pacific''-class patrol boat]]s, the ''Auki'' and the ''Lata''. Defense and policing assistance was the responsibility of the [[RAMSI]] until June 30, 2017. |align=center|<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27 |url=http://www.defence.gov.au/minister/NelsonMintpl.cfm?CurrentId=5664 |title=Australian defence presence in solomon islands |publisher=Australian Government Department of Defense |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080817231336/http://defence.gov.au/minister/NelsonMintpl.cfm?CurrentId=5664 |archivedate=August 17, 2008 }}</ref><ref>[http://britains-smallwars.com/RRGP/Solomons.html The Solomons Islands 1998-2003] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120509185544/http://britains-smallwars.com/RRGP/Solomons.html |date=2012-05-09 }}, [http://britains-smallwars.com/ britains-smallwars.com/].</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2011/solomon-islands |title=Solomon Islands |publisher=Freedom House |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bp.html |title=CIA - The World Factbook |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ramsi.org/ |title=Regional Assistance Mission to Solomon Islands - Home |publisher=RAMSI |date=2012-04-26 |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Tuvalu}} | Since the country's foundation [[Military of Tuvalu|no military]] has been formed; however, there is a small [[Law enforcement in Tuvalu|police force]], and a [[Military of Tuvalu|Maritime Surveillance Unit]] for internal security. The Maritime Surveillance Unit is equipped with small arms, and maintains one [[Pacific class patrol boat|''Pacific''-class patrol boat]], the ''Te Mataili''. |align=center|<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27|url=http://www.wpro.who.int/countries/tuv/|title=Country Context |publisher=World Health Organization }}</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">http://www.vanuatu.usp.ac.fj/library/Paclaw/Tuvalu/Police%20Act.pdf</ref><ref name="autogenerated1"/> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Vatican City}} | Maintains a [[Corps of Gendarmerie of Vatican City|Gendarmerie Corps]] for internal policing. The [[Pontifical Swiss Guard]] is an armed unit charged with protecting the Pope, although it is officially under the authority of the [[Holy See]], not the Vatican City State. There is no defense treaty with [[Italy]], as it would violate the Vatican's neutrality, but informally the [[Italian Armed Forces]] protect Vatican City. The [[Palatine Guard]] and [[Noble Guard (Vatican)|Noble Guard]] were abolished in 1970. |align=center|<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27 |url=http://dev.prenhall.com/divisions/hss/worldreference/VA/defense.html |title=Vatican City |publisher=World Desk Reference |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061122145658/http://dev.prenhall.com/divisions/hss/worldreference/VA/defense.html |archivedate=November 22, 2006 }}</ref><ref>http://www.miwsr.com/2012/downloads/2012-008.pdf</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/vt.html |title=CIA - The World Factbook |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/The-Popes-Soldiers-Military-History/dp/0700617701 |title=The Pope's Soldiers: A Military History of the Modern Vatican Modern War Studies: Amazon.co.uk: David Alvarez: Books |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> |}
== Countries with no standing army but limited military== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" |- |+Countries with no standing army, but having limited military forces !scope=col| Country !scope=col| Comments !scope=col| Ref(s) |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Costa Rica}} |The constitution has forbidden a [[Military of Costa Rica|standing military]] since 1949. It does have a [[Public Forces of Costa Rica|public security force]] with limited military capacities, whose main role includes law enforcement and internal security. For this reason Costa Rica is the headquarters for the [[Inter-American Court of Human Rights]] and also the [[United Nations]]' [[University for Peace]]. | align=center|<ref name="costa rica">{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27 |url=http://dev.prenhall.com/divisions/hss/worldreference/CR/defense.html |title=Costa Rica |publisher=World Desk Reference |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080211185659/http://dev.prenhall.com/divisions/hss/worldreference/CR/defense.html |archivedate=February 11, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elespiritudel48.org/docu/h013.htm|author=El Espíritu del 48|title=Abolición del Ejército|accessdate=2008-03-09}} (Spanish)</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Iceland}} | Has not had a [[standing army]] since 1869, but is an active member of [[NATO]]. There was a defense agreement with the [[United States]], which maintained an [[Iceland Defense Force]] and a military base in the country from 1951 to 2006. [[Naval Air Station Keflavik]] closed in late 2006 after 55 years. However, the U.S. announced it would continue to provide for Iceland's defense, but without permanently basing forces in the country. Even though Iceland does not have a standing army, it still maintains a [[Icelandic Crisis Response Unit|military expeditionary peacekeeping force]], an [[Iceland Air Defence System|air defence system]], an extensive [[Icelandic Coast Guard|militarised coast guard]], a [[Icelandic Police|police service]], and a [[Víkingasveitin|tactical police force]]. There are also agreements regarding military and other security operations with [[Norway]], [[Denmark]], and other NATO countries. |align=center|<ref name="iceland">{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27|url=http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/dod/idf.htm|title=Iceland Defense Force |publisher=Global Security }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/3396.htm |title=U.S. Department of State: Iceland |publisher=State.gov |date=2011-11-08 |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.regjeringen.no/en/dep/ud/Press-Contacts/News/2007/mou-2.html?id=464488 |title=A press release from the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs |publisher=Regjeringen.no |date=2007-04-26 |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.regjeringen.no/upload/UD/Vedlegg/icelandmou.pdf |title=An English translation of the Norwegian-Icelandic MoU at the website of the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs. |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>[http://www.norwaypost.no/cgi-bin/norwaypost/imaker?id=72317 Norway Post: Norway and Iceland to sign defence agreement] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929092727/http://www.norwaypost.no/cgi-bin/norwaypost/imaker?id=72317 |date=September 29, 2007 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article1753031.ece Aftenposten: Norway to help defend Iceland] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629022120/http://www.aftenposten.no/english/local/article1753031.ece |date=June 29, 2011 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dr.dk/Nyheder/Indland/2007/04/26/120138.htm?rss=true |title=Danmarks Radio |publisher=Dr.dk |date=2007-04-26 |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{nowrap|{{flagcountry|Mauritius}}}} | Mauritius has not had a standing army since 1968. All military, police, and security functions are carried out by 10,000 active duty personnel under the command of the [[Mauritius#Military and police|Commissioner of Police]]. The 8,000 member [[Mauritius Police Force|National Police Force]] is responsible for domestic law enforcement. There is also a 1,500 member [[Special Mobile Force]], and a 500-member [[Military of Mauritius#Navy|National Coast Guard]], which are both considered paramilitary units. Both units are equipped with small arms. |align=center|<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27|url=https://www.state.gov/r/pa/ei/bgn/2833.htm|title=Background Note: Mauritius |publisher=United States Department of State }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nationmaster.com/country/mp-mauritius/mil-military |title=Mauritian Military Data |publisher=Nationmaster.com |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/mp.html |title=CIA - The World Factbook |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Monaco}} | Renounced its general military investment in the 17th century because the advancement in artillery technology had rendered it defenseless, but still self-identifies as having limited military forces. Although defense is the responsibility of [[France]], two [[Military of Monaco|small military units]] are maintained; one primarily protects the [[Prince of Monaco|Prince]] and judiciary, while the other is responsible for civil defense and fire fighting. Both units are well-trained and equipped with small arms. In addition to the military, an armed national [[Law enforcement in Monaco|police force]] is maintained for internal security purposes. |align=center|<ref name="monaco">{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27 |url=http://www.monaco-consulate.com/news_1024.htm |title=Monaco signs new treaty with France |publisher=Monaco Consulate |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071021034944/http://www.monaco-consulate.com/news_1024.htm |archivedate=2007-10-21 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>[http://www.pompiers.gouv.mc/321/wwwnew.nsf/1909!/x1Fr?OpenDocument&1Fr] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206010807/http://www.pompiers.gouv.mc/321/wwwnew.nsf/1909%21/x1Fr?OpenDocument&1Fr |date=December 6, 2013 }}</ref><ref>[http://www.pompiers.gouv.mc/321/wwwnew.nsf/1909$/db4c6e6016593114c1257163004604b2fr?OpenDocument&1Fr] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130812025216/http://www.pompiers.gouv.mc/321/wwwnew.nsf/1909%24/db4c6e6016593114c1257163004604b2fr?OpenDocument&1Fr |date=August 12, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.palais.mc/monaco/palais-princier/francais/maison-souveraine/la-compagnie-des-carabiniers/la-compagnie-des-carabiniers-de-s-a-s-le-prince.70.html |title=La Compagnie des Carabiniers de S.A.S. le Prince - Palais Princier de Monaco |publisher=Palais.mc |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120609024338/http://www.palais.mc/monaco/palais-princier/francais/maison-souveraine/la-compagnie-des-carabiniers/la-compagnie-des-carabiniers-de-s-a-s-le-prince.70.html |archivedate=2012-06-09 |df= }}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Panama}} | [[Military of Panama|Abolished its army]] in 1990, which was confirmed by a unanimous parliamentary vote for constitutional change in 1994. The [[Panamanian Public Forces]] include the National Police, National Borders Service, National Aeronaval Service, and Institutional Protection Service, which have some warfare capabilities. |align=center|<ref>{{cite web|accessdate=2008-02-27|url=http://lcweb2.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?frd/cstdy:@field(DOCID+pa0104)|title=The Panama Defense Forces |publisher=Library of Congress }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/pm.html |title=CIA - The World Factbook |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.photius.com/wfb1999/panama/panama_military.html |title=Panama military - Flags, Maps, Economy, Geography, Climate, Natural Resources, Current Issues, International Agreements, Population, Social Statistics, Political System |publisher=Photius.com |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> |- !scope=row| {{flagcountry|Vanuatu}} | The [[Law enforcement in Vanuatu|Vanuatu Police Force]] maintain a paramilitary force, called the [[Military of Vanuatu|Vanuatu Mobile Force]] for internal security purposes. The Vanuatu Mobile Force is manned by almost 300 men and women, who are well-equipped with small arms. |align=center|<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2011/vanuatu |title=Vanuatu |publisher=Freedom House |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://epress.anu.edu.au/kastom/mobile_devices/ch05s02.html |title=The Vanuatu Police Force |publisher=Epress.anu.edu.au |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/nh.html |title=CIA - The World Factbook |publisher=Cia.gov |date= |accessdate=2012-06-17}}</ref> |}
==See also== *[[List of countries by military expenditures]] *[[List of countries by number of military and paramilitary personnel]] *[[List of militaries that recruit foreigners]]
==Notes== {{Reflist|30em}}
==References== * {{cite book|author=Barbey, Christophe |title=La non-militarisation et les pays sans armée : une réalité |language=French |publisher=APRED |location=Flendruz [Vaud, Switzerland] |year=2001}} * {{cite book|author=Barbey, Christophe |title=Non-militarisation: Countries without Armies: Identification Criteria and First Findings |publisher=The Åland Islands Peace Institute |series=Working Papers from the Åland Islands Peace Institute |location=Mariehamn [Finland] |year=2015 |isbn= |url=http://www.peace.ax/en/nyhetsarkiv/1922-working-paper-on-countries-without-armies}}

page.title: List of extreme points of Greece

revision.text:
This is a list of the '''extreme points of [[Greece]]''', the points that are farther [[north]], [[south]], [[east]] or [[west]] than any other location.
{{Location map+ | Greece | caption = Latitude and longitude extremities of [[Greece]] | places = {{Location map~ | Greece | label = [[Ormenio]] | lat_deg=41.733333 | lon_deg=26.183333 }} {{Location map~ | Greece | label = [[Tenaro|Cape Tenaro]] | lat_deg = 36.383333 | lon_deg = 22.483333 }} {{Location map~ | Greece | label = [[Sagiada]] | lat_deg = 39.683333 | lon_deg = 19.983333 }} {{Location map~ | Greece | label = [[Pythio]] | lat_deg = 41.383333 | lon_deg = 26.633333}} {{Location map~ | Greece | label = [[Gavdos]] | lat_deg = 34.816667 | lon_deg = 24.116667}} {{Location map~ | Greece | label = [[Othonoi]] | lat_deg = 39.85 | lon_deg = 19.383333}} {{Location map~ | Greece | label = [[Strongyli Kastellorizou|Strongyli]] | lat_deg = 36.116667 | lon_deg = 29.641667}} }}
==Mainland== *Northernmost point — Gravia area, [[Evros (regional unit)|Evros regional unit]] ({{coord|41|44|56|N|26|13|48|E|region:GR_type:landmark}}) *Northernmost settlement — [[Ormenio]], [[Evros (regional unit)|Evros regional unit]] ({{coord|41|43|13|N|26|12|48|E|region:GR_type:landmark}}) *Southernmost point — Cape [[Tenaro]], also Cape Matapan, the [[Peloponnese]] ({{coord|36|23|08|N|22|28|59|E|region:GR_type:landmark}}) *Southernmost settlement — [[Kokkinogia]], the [[Peloponnese]] ({{coord|36|24|14|N|22|29|12|E|region:GR_type:landmark}}) *Westernmost point — Ftelia Bay (Ormos Ftelias), [[Thesprotia]] ({{coord|39|41|25|N|20|00|41|E|region:GR_type:landmark}}) *Westernmost settlement — [[Skala Sagiadas]], [[Thesprotia]] ({{coord|39|37|38|N|20|11|06|E|region:GR_type:landmark}}) *Easternmost point — unnamed river island, [[Evros River]], Evros regional unit ({{coord|41|23|04|N|26|38|07|E|region:GR_type:landmark}}) *Easternmost settlement — [[Stathmos Pythiou]], Evros regional unit ({{coord|41|22|17|N|26|37|17|E|region:GR_type:landmark}})
==Entire Greece== *Northernmost point — Gravia area, [[Evros (regional unit)|Evros regional unit]] ({{coord|41|44|56|N|26|13|48|E|region:GR_type:landmark}}) *Northernmost settlement — [[Ormenio]], [[Evros (regional unit)|Evros regional unit]] ({{coord|41|43|13|N|26|12|48|E|region:GR_type:landmark}}) *Southernmost point — [[Cape Trypiti]] ({{coord|34|48|03|N|24|07|20|E|region:GR_type:landmark}}). It is also the southernmost point of Europe. *Southernmost settlement — [[Vatsiana]] ({{coord|34|49|14|N|24|05|55|E|region:GR_type:landmark}}) *Westernmost point — Xilosermi beach, [[Othonoi]], off [[Corfu]] ({{coord|39|51|07|N|19|22|26|E|region:GR_type:landmark}}) *Westernmost settlement — [[Chorio, Othonoi|Chorio]], [[Othonoi]], off [[Corfu]] ({{coord|39|51|12|N|19|22|56|E|region:GR_type:landmark}}) *Easternmost point — islet of [[Strongyli Kastellorizou|Strongyli]], in the [[Megisti]] archipelago ({{coord|36|06|58|N|29|38|43|E|region:GR_type:landmark}}) *Easternmost settlement — [[Kastellorizo]], in the [[Megisti]] archipelago ({{coord|36|08|54|N|29|35|30|E|region:GR_type:landmark}}) *Highest point — the peak of [[Mount Olympus]], 2917 m *Lowest point — sea level <ref>{{cite web|last1=CIA|title=Europe::Greece|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/gr.html|website=The World Factbook|publisher=CIA|accessdate=7 October 2016}}</ref> *Deepest point — [[Calypso Deep]], [[Ionian Sea]], -5267 m. It is also the deepest point of the [[Mediterranean Sea]].
==Historical== Upon liberation of Greece in '''1830''', the extreme points of the country were:
*North: [[Psathoura]] island (39.498°N 24.181°E) in the Northern [[Sporades]], NE of [[Alonnisos]] *South: [[Eschati]] (Mermengas) islet in the Cyclades, around 10 miles SW of [[Santorini]] *East: [[Amorgos]] island (36°50′N 25°54′E) and in particular the eastern tip thereof, east of Aegiali village *West: [[Forti]] islet in the Ionian Sea, in the narrow straits between the island of [[Lefkas]] (still under British rule) and the coast of [[Acarnania]] province of the [[Aetolia-Acarnania]] prefecture, to which it belonged
Upon granting of the Ionian Islands to Greece in '''1864''' the extreme points of the country were modified as follows:
*North & West: [[Sazan Island]] (''Sason, Saso'') (40°30′N 19°17′E) at the entrance of the [[Bay of Vlorë]] (''Aulon, Avlona'') *South: [[Antikythera]] (35°52′N 23°18′E) == See also == *[[Extreme points of Earth]] *[[Geography of Greece]]
==References== <references />
{{Extreme points of Europe}}
[[Category:Geography of Greece]] [[Category:Extreme points by country|Greece]] [[Category:Greece geography-related lists|Extreme]]

page.title: List of postal codes in Slovakia

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
'''Slovak Post''' (Slovenská pošta) in 2006 offered a service for the lookup of [[postal code]]s (poštové smerové číslo PSČ) in [[Slovakia]]. The service works in both [[Slovak language|Slovak]] and [[English language|English]]. The Post offers the ability to search postal codes of towns and streets (see the list below of towns where a street code is needed) or to search by town and company name. Furthermore, the list of postcodes is available as a [[ZIP file]].
==Usage==
Postal codes need to be written '''before''' the name of the town, and no shortening of the official state name (e.g. 'SK') is permitted.
== Slovak towns with individual streets postal codes ==
*Bánovce nad Bebravou *Banská Bystrica *Banská Štiavnica *Bratislava and all its city parts: **Nové Mesto **Petržalka **Rača **Ružinov **Dúbravka **Karlova Ves **Devínska Nová Ves **Staré Mesto *Brezno *Čadca *Dargovských Hrdinov (Košice) *Hlohovec *Hurbanovo *Komárno *Košice *Kysucké Nové Mesto *Levice *Liptovský Mikuláš *Lučenec *Luník IX (Košice) *Martin *Myjava *Nad Jazerom (Košice) *Nitra *Nové Zámky *Partizánske *Pezinok *Podunajské Biskupice *Považská Bystrica *Prešov *Ružomberok *Sever (Košice) *Sídlisko KVP (Košice) *Sídlisko Ťahanovce (Košice) *Spišská Nová Ves *Šaľa *Štúrovo *Topoľčany *Trenčín *Trnava *Vranov nad Topľou *Zlaté Moravce *Zvolen *Žilina
==References / External links== * 1. [http://www.posta.sk/subory/322/psc-obci-a-ulic.zip Zip download site] * 2. [https://web.archive.org/web/20060509011623/http://www.slposta.sk/index.php?id=266 Towns and streets index] * 3. [https://web.archive.org/web/20060928173205/http://www.slposta.sk/index.php?id=269 Town and company name index]
[[Category:Lists of postal codes|Slovakia]] [[Category:Slovakia communications-related lists|Postal codes]] [[Category:Postal system of Slovakia]]

page.title: List of presidential trips made by Barack Obama during 2014

revision.text:
{{main|Presidency of Barack Obama}} [[File:Barack Obama and Shinzo Abe at Sukyabashi Jiro April 2014.jpg|thumb|Obama dining with Japanese Prime Minister [[Shinzō Abe]] at [[Sukiyabashi Jiro]] during his visit to [[Tokyo]], Japan, April 23, 2014]] This is a '''list of presidential trips made by [[Barack Obama]] during 2014''', the sixth year of [[Presidency of Barack Obama|his presidency]] as the [[List of Presidents of the United States|44th]] [[President of the United States]]. This list excludes trips made within [[Washington, D.C.]], the U.S. federal capital in which the [[White House]], the official residence and principal workplace of the President, is located. Additionally excluded are trips to [[Camp David]], the country residence of the President, and to the private home of the [[Family of Barack Obama|Obama family]] in [[Kenwood, Chicago|Kenwood]], [[Chicago]]. ==January== {| class="wikitable" style="margin: 1em auto 1em auto" |- ! width=100|Country/
''U.S. state'' ! width=100|Areas visited ! width=60|Date(s) ! width=550|Details |- |{{Flagicon|North Carolina}} ''[[North Carolina]]'' |[[Raleigh, North Carolina|Raleigh]] |January 15 |President Obama toured [[Vacon]] facilities and delivered remarks at the [[North Carolina State University]], regarding manufacturing jobs.{{cite web|last1=Slack|first1=Megan|title=North Carolina Is Home to America’s Newest High-Tech Manufacturing Hub|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2014/01/15/north-carolina-home-america-s-newest-high-tech-manufacturing-hub|website=[[WhiteHouse.gov]]|accessdate=March 28, 2015|date=January 15, 2014}}{{cite news|title=President Obama announces new Raleigh-based manufacturing institute during North Carolina visit|url=http://abc11.com/politics/obama-unveils-plan-for-nc-innovation-hub/34877/|accessdate=March 28, 2015|publisher=[[WTVD]]|date=January 15, 2014}} |- |{{Flagicon|Pennsylvania}} ''[[Pennsylvania]]'' |[[Pittsburgh]] |January 29 |President Obama signed the [[myRA|''my''RA]] program and delivered remarks at [[U.S. Steel]]'s [[Mon Valley Works–Irvin Plant|Irvin plant]].{{cite news|last1=O'Toole|first1=James|title=President Obama delivers speech in West Robot|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/tech/innovation/obama-gets-kick-out-soccer-playing-asimo-robot-n88631|accessdate=March 29, 2015|publisher=[[NBC News]]|date=April 24, 2014}} before attending a [[state Korea]] |[[Seoul]] |April 25–26 |President Obama attended a wreath-laying ceremony at the [[War Memorial of Korea]] and visited [[Gyeongbokgung]], before meeting with [[President of South Korea|President]] [[Park Geun-hye]] at the [[Blue House]] to discuss [[North Korea]]'s [[Nuclear power in North Korea|nuclear threat]] and the U.S.-Korea Free Trade Agreement. In the wake of the [[Sinking of the MV Sewol|sinking]] of the [[MV Sewol|MV ''Sewol'']], President Obama also presented President Park with the [[Flag of the United States|American flag]] that flew over the White House during the day of the disaster (April 16), as well as presenting a [[magnolia]] seed to the [[Danwon High School]], which victimized a number of the high school's students and teachers. The following day, the President met with American and Korean business leaders to discuss the trade and economic cooperation between the two countries and delivered remarks at [[Yongsan Garrison]].{{cite web|last1=Kim|first1=Ellen|title=President Obama’s Visit to South Korea|url=http://cogitasia.com/president-obamas-visit-to-south-korea/|publisher=[[Center for Strategic and International Studies]]|accessdate=March 29, 2015|date=April 29, 2014}}{{cite news|last1=Landler|first1=Mark|title=Obama Offers Support to South Korea at a Moment of Trauma and Tension|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/04/26/world/asia/obama-asia.html?_r=0|accessdate=March 29, 2015|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=April 25, 2014}} |- |{{flagicon|Malaysia}} [[Malaysia]] |[[Kuala Lumpur]] |April 26–28 |President Obama was greeted with a welcoming ceremony outside the [[Malaysian Houses of Parliament]], where he was accompanied by [[Yang di-Pertuan Agong]] [[Abdul Halim of Kedah|Abdul Halim]] and [[Prime Minister of Malaysia|Prime Minister]] [[Najib Razak]].{{cite news|title=As Obama arrives, Zaid slams Putrajaya’s inability to say hudud is unacceptable|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/as-obama-arrives-zaid-slams-putrajayas-inability-to-say-hudud-is-unacceptab|accessdate=March 30, 2015|publisher=''[[The Malay Mail]]''|date=April 26, 2014}} In the evening, the President was also hosted a state dinner by Yang di-Pertuan Agong Abdul Halim and [[Raja Permaisuri Agong]] [[Sultanah Haminah Hamidun]] at the [[Istana Negara, Jalan Duta|Istana Negara]].{{cite news|last1=Superville|first1=Darlene|title=Royal welcome for Obama on historic Malaysia trip|url=http://www.theoaklandpress.com/general-news/20140426/royal-welcome-for-obama-on-historic-malaysia-trip|accessdate=March 30, 2015|agency=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=''[[The Oakland Press]]''|date=April 26, 2014}} On April 27, President Obama visited the [[National Mosque of Malaysia]], before holding a bilateral meeting and a joint press conference with Prime Minister Najib at the [[Perdana Putra]] to discuss issues on trade, defense, and maritime security, as well as the United States' commitment to contributing to the [[Search for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370|search]] for [[Malaysia Airlines Flight 370]].{{cite news|title=Obama says US committed to providing assets for MH370 ocean search|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/obama-says-us-committed-to-providing-assets-for-mh370-ocean-search|accessdate=March 30, 2015|publisher=''[[The Malay Mail]]''|date=April 27, 2014}} He also delivered remarks at the [[Malaysian Global Innovation and Creativity Centre]] and participated in the Young Southeast Asian Leaders Initiative Town Hall meeting at the [[University of Malaya]]. |- |{{flagicon|Philippines}} [[Philippines]] |[[Manila]],
[[Taguig]] |April 28–29 |President Obama met with [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Benigno Aquino III]] at the [[Malacañang Palace]] to discuss efforts in resolving the territorial and maritime disputes in the South China Sea and the enhancement of the two countries' security and strategic cooperation with the signing of the [[Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement]], which was followed by a joint press conference.{{cite web|title=Remarks by President Obama and President Benigno Aquino III of the Philippines in Joint Press Conference|url=https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2014/04/28/remarks-president-obama-and-president-benigno-aquino-iii-philippines-joi|website=[[WhiteHouse.gov]]|accessdate=March 30, A '''little Switzerland''' or '''''Schweiz''''' is a [[landscape]], often of wooded hills. This [[Romanticism|Romantic]] aesthetic term is not a geographic category, but was widely used in the 19th century to connote dramatic natural scenic features that would be of interest to tourists. Since it was ambiguous from the very beginning, it was flexibly used in travel writing to imply that a landscape had some features, though on a much smaller scale, that might remind a visitor of [[Switzerland]].
== Rock outcrops == [[Image:Bastei - Die Bastei vom Elbe-Aussichtspunkt.jpg|thumb|The [[Bastei]], [[Saxon Switzerland]]]] [[Image:Rochedoetre.jpg|thumb|[[Rock of Oëtre]], [[Norman Switzerland]]]]
The original generic term was applied to dozens of locations in Europe, the bulk of them German-speaking, as well as to other parts of the world, to direct attention to rock outcrops that stand out, usually amid steep forest. The original, 18th-century comparison was usually with the fissured crags of the [[Jura Mountains]] on the Franco-Swiss border which hardly rise higher than 1700 metres.
Histories of [[Saxon Switzerland]] (''Sächsische Schweiz'') in Saxony, Germany, assert that the landscape description ''schweiz'' arose there at the end of the 18th century. ''Schweiz'' is the German-language name of Switzerland. The term was used both alone and with the prefix "little", for example in the title of an 1820 German book-length poem, ''Die kleine Schweiz'' by Jakob Reiselsberger,<ref>Reiselsberger, Jakob; Die kleine Schweiz oder Einladung zur Reise nach Streitberg, Muggendorf, Weischenfeld [et]c. und deren Umgebungen; Leitfaden für hieher Reisende, Höhlen-Besucher, Natur- und Alterthums-Freunde, und schön unterhaltendes Taschenbuch für jedermann; [S.l.] 1820</ref> which praised the rocky scenery of a part of [[Franconia]] in Germany known thereafter as the [[Franconian Switzerland]] (''Fränkische Schweiz'').
The term was already colloquial by this time in English: in 1823 a correspondent asserted in ''[[The Gentleman's Magazine]]'' that a steep area by the road outside [[Petersfield, Hampshire|Petersfield]] in southern England was a little Switzerland.<ref>''The Gentleman's Magazine'', London; December 1823, page 506</ref> The aesthetic term, to describe picturesque exposed rock and steepness rather than altitude, was also in common use in other European languages, including the French term ''Suisse''. Rocks and wild landscapes were a favoured theme in [[Romanticism|Romantic]] painting.
The many English places praised in 19th-century promotional literature as "little Switzerland" include [[Church Stretton]], [[Whitfield, Northumberland|Whitfield]] and the coastal area around the [[North Devon]] twin towns of Lynton and [[Lynmouth]]. Chalet-style buildings were sometimes erected to emphasize little Switzerland pretensions, for example at [[Matlock Bath railway station|Matlock Bath]], which (unusually for England) also features a [[Aerial lift|cable car]].
== Mountains ==
From the beginning, the term was often understood as a comparison to the snow-capped Alps rather than to the Jura. The following passage, describing Wales, appears in an 1831 English-language edition of [[Conrad Malte-Brun|Malte-Brun's]] ''Universal Geography'', which had originally been written in French in 1803–07:
{{cquote|The great number of mountains which diversify its surface have gained it the name of Little Switzerland. It will be readily understood that it is not in the loftiness of their summits this resemblance can be traced with the country of the Alps, but in their steep, rough and perpendicular sides, the depth of their narrow valleys, the small but limpid lakes which occur at every step, the great number of rivers and streams which are now precipitated in cascades, and now roll their waters slowly through the meadows, the damp fogs which rise from the surface of these waters and often hang about the summits of the highest mountains, and the snow which frequently continues upon the heights till the end of spring: all of which give to these mountains, notwithstanding their inconsiderable height ... an appearance resembling those lordly eminences mounting up to the clouds and bearing on their heads eternal snows.<ref>Malte-Brun, Conrad; Universal Geography: Or, a Description of All Parts of the World, on a New Plan; Boston, Lilly and Wait, 1831, volume 1, page 742</ref>}}
Describing the Atlantic island of St Helena in ''A New Voyage Round the World'' (1823–26), [[Otto von Kotzebue]] and [[Johann Friedrich Eschscholtz]] were translated into English as writing:
{{cquote|The environs of Sandy Bay would be a perfect little Switzerland, but that the glaciers are wanting to complete the resemblance. Scattered among the enormous masses of rock which lie confusedly heaped upon each other a frightful wilderness and most smilingly picturesque landscape alternately present their contrasted images.<ref>Kotzebue, Otto von and Johann Friedrich Eschscholtz; A New Voyage Round the World in the Years 1823, 24, 25, and 26; Colburn and Bentley, 1830, page 317</ref>}}
In the United States, the raw [[White Mountains (New Hampshire)|White Mountains]] of New Hampshire, which were soon to be one of the definitive subjects of American Romantic [[White Mountain art|painting]], were termed a little Switzerland by travel writer Henry Tudor as early as 1832.<ref>Tudor, Henry; Narrative of a Tour in North America; London, James Duncan, 1834, page 390</ref>
== Lakelands == [[Image:Plön Panorama Ploener See.jpg|thumb|[[Lake Plön]] in [[Holstein Switzerland]]]]
In the later 19th century, authors and tourism promoters would praise picture-postcard summer scenery of woods and low hills reflected in blue lakes as a little Switzerland or ''schweiz''. Whereas the earlier use had implied a landscape of dangers, this was a term for beauty.
This usage, reflected today in the official geographical terms for the [[Holstein Switzerland]] (''Holsteinische Schweiz'') and [[Mecklenburgische Schweiz|Mecklenburg Switzerland]] (''Mecklenburgische Schweiz'') in Germany, where there are neither mountains nor outcrops, is difficult to account for, but may refer to prestigious Swiss lakeside tourist destinations such as Zurich, Lucerne or [[Interlaken]] or to Lakes Geneva and Constance.
== Official names ==
The term has often appeared anachronistic since travel to Switzerland became affordable. By the 21st century, it was common for observers to express puzzlement that the "little Switzerland" label applied at all to regions such as the Suisse Normande, or to the Holstein Switzerland where the flat hilltops are no more than 150 metres above the lake surfaces.
In 1992, the Swiss Tourism Federation counted<ref>[http://www.fraenkische-schweiz.com/info/hintergrund/name_fs_entstehung.htm ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061019142004/http://www.fraenkische-schweiz.com/info/hintergrund/name_fs_entstehung.htm |date=October 19, 2006 }}</ref> more than 190 places round the world that had at least for some period been named after Switzerland, either because of a fancied scenic resemblance, in jest or referring to a banking haven, political neutrality or habitation by Swiss emigrants. No fewer than 67 places in neighbouring Germany were said by the Federation to have adopted little Switzerland names.
While the byname has fallen out of fashion in some places, it persists as the official geographical name for several administrative regions and national parks including (with dates of legal designation): * [[Bohemian Switzerland]] (''České Švýcarsko'', nature park, Czech Republic, legislation with effect 2000)<ref>http://www.ceskesvycarsko.cz/bohemian-switzerland-national-park</ref> * [[Bremen Switzerland]] (undulating [[geest]] north of Bremen, that reaches 30 m; c.f. the flat land on which Bremen is built.) * [[Franconian Switzerland]] (tourism region, Germany, designated 1968)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsvf.de/?id=58 |title=Naturpark |publisher=Fsvf.de |date= |accessdate=2013-11-27}}</ref> * [[Hersbruck Switzerland]] (''Hersbrucker Schweiz''), low mountain region around Hersbruck, Germany * [[Hohburg Switzerland]] (''Hohburger Schweiz''), alternative name for the Hohburg Hills near Leipzig * [[Holstein Switzerland]] ([[Holstein Switzerland Nature Park|nature park]], Germany, formed by association 1986) * [[Szwajcaria Kaszubska|Kashubian Switzerland]] (Szwajcaria Kaszubska, Poland) * [[Kroppach Switzerland]], rocky upland region near [[Kroppach]] in the [[Westerwald]] * [[Märkische Schweiz Nature Park|Marcher Switzerland]] (''Märkische Schweiz'', nature park, Germany, by decree 1990)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.grossschutzgebiete.brandenburg.de/np_ms/gebiete_01.html |title=Naturpark Märkische Schweiz | LUGV |publisher=Grossschutzgebiete.brandenburg.de |date=2013-06-24 |accessdate=2013-11-27}}</ref> * [[Mecklenburg Switzerland]] (nature park, Germany, designated 1997)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naturpark-mecklenburgische-schweiz.de/ |title=naturpark-mecklenburgische-schweiz.de |publisher=naturpark-mecklenburgische-schweiz.de |date= |accessdate=2013-11-27}}</ref> * [[Rhenish-Hessian Switzerland]] (protected landscape and recreation area in [[Rhineland-Palatinate]]). * [[Rostock Switzerland]] (rugged terminal moraine landscape near the Baltic coast in [[Mecklenburg-Vorpommern]]). * [[Rüdigsdorf Switzerland]] (hill range and karst landscape in the southern [[Harz]], most of which is a nature reserve) * [[Ruppin Switzerland]] (a forested lakeland in [[Brandenburg]]) * [[Saxon Switzerland]] (nature park, Germany, designated 1990;<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nationalpark-saechsische-schweiz.de/red1/sachsens-nationalpark/kurzportrait/ |title=Kurzportrait des Schutzgebietes |publisher=Nationalpark-saechsische-schweiz.de |date=2013-07-15 |accessdate=2013-11-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061130034932/http://www.nationalpark-saechsische-schweiz.de/red1/sachsens-nationalpark/kurzportrait/ |archivedate=2006-11-30 |df= }}</ref> local government area, now in [[Sächsische Schweiz-Osterzgebirge|Saxon Switzerland-East Ore Mountains]] district)
Business promotion regions using the name without legally defined boundaries include: * [[Norman Switzerland|Suisse Normande]] (upland region of [[Calvados (department)|Calvados]], France) * [[Little Switzerland (Luxembourg)]] (dolomite formations near [[Echternach, Luxembourg]])<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.berdorf.lu/ |title=berdorf.lu |publisher=berdorf.lu |date= |accessdate=2013-11-27}}</ref>
Notable privately developed properties known by the name include: * [[Little Switzerland, North Carolina]] (resort development on hilltop in North Carolina, USA, from 1909)<ref>[http://www.newsobserver.com/105/story/501546.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311175358/http://www.newsobserver.com/105/story/501546.html |date=March 11, 2007 }}</ref> * [[Little Switzerland (Wisconsin)]] (a ski resort from 1941 onwards)
== Usage == In English, "Little Switzerland" is usually said without any definite article or additional adjective, but often with a genitive modifier if there are several little Switzerlands within one nation, e.g. North Carolina's Little Switzerland. In European languages where Switzerland proper takes a definite article, little Switzerlands do likewise. Their English names may echo the vernacular, being capitalized and modified to the English alphabet, sometimes taking an English definite article, e.g. the Saechsische Schweiz (''die Sächsische Schweiz'') and the Suisse Normande (''la Suisse normande''). English forms are also widespread, e.g. Holstein Switzerland (Dickinson, 1964),<ref>{{Dickinson's Germany}}</ref> Swiss Franconia (Michelin, 1993),<ref>''Germany, Michelin Tourist Guide'', 1st Edition, 1993, Clermont-Ferrand, p 59.</ref> Franconian Switzerland (Fodor, 1962,<ref>Fodor, Eugene; ''Fodor's Modern Guides: Germany'', MacGibbon & Kee, 1962, The Hague, p. 249.</ref> and Bolt, 2005.<ref>Bolt, Rodney, ''Bavaria'', London, 2005, pp. 203-204, {{ISBN|1-86011-202-1}}.</ref>)
==See also== {{portal|Switzerland}} *[[Geography of Switzerland]]
