'''Road ecology''' is the study of the [[Environmental issue|ecological effects]] (both positive and negative) of [[road]]s and [[highway]]s (public roads). These effects may include local effects, such as on [[noise pollution|noise]], [[water pollution]], [[habitat destruction]]/disturbance and local [[air quality]]; and wider effects such as [[habitat fragmentation]], ecosystem degradation, and [[climate change]] from vehicle emissions.
The design, construction and management of [[roads]], [[parking]] and other related facilities as well as the design and regulation of [[vehicle]]s can change their effect. Roads are known to cause significant [[forest destruction|damage to forests]], prairies, streams and [[wetlands]].<ref name="Forman">{{cite book|author1=Forman, R.T.T. |author2=Sperling, D. |author3=Bissonette, J.A. |author4=Clevenger, A.P. |author5=Cutshall, C.D. |author6=Dale, V.H. |author7=Fahrig, L. |author8=France, R.L. |author9=Goldman, C.R. |author10=Heanue, K. |year=2002|title=Road Ecology: Science and Solutions|publisher=Island Press|isbn=9781559639330|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=As1yk7rRUhsC|}}</ref> Besides the direct habitat loss due to the road itself, and the [[roadkill]] of animal species, roads alter water-flow patterns, increase [[noise pollution|noise]], [[water pollution|water]], and [[air pollution]], create disturbance that alters the [[species composition]] of nearby vegetation thereby reducing habitat for local native animals, and act as barriers to animal movements. Roads are a form of [[Linear infrastructure intrusions|linear infrastructure intrusion]] that has some effects similar to infrastructure such as railroads, power lines, and canals, particularly in [[tropical forest]]s.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Laurance|first=William F.|last2=Goosem|first2=Miriam|last3=Laurance|first3=Susan G.W.|title=Impacts of roads and linear clearings on tropical forests|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.tree.2009.06.009|journal=Trends in Ecology & Evolution|volume=24|issue=12|pages=659–669|doi=10.1016/j.tree.2009.06.009}}</ref>
Road ecology is practiced as a field of inquiry by a variety of ecologists, biologists, [[hydrologist]]s, engineers, and other scientists. There are several global centers for the study of road ecology: 1) The Road Ecology Center <ref>[http://roadecology.ucdavis.edu] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180308232133/https://roadecology.ucdavis.edu/ |date=2018-03-08 }}</ref> at the University of California, Davis, which was the first of its kind in the world; 2) the Centro Brasileiro de Estudos em Ecologia de Estradas at the Federal University of Lavras, Brazil;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cbee.ufla.br/portal/ |title=Portal CBEE · Centro Brasileiro de Estudos em Ecologia de Estradas |website=Cbee.ufla.br |date= |accessdate=2017-05-23}}</ref> 3) The Center for Transportation and the Environment, North Carolina State University;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cte.ncsu.edu/ |title=Center for Transportation and the Environment (CTE) |website=Cte.ncsu.edu |date=2014-08-19 |accessdate=2017-05-23}}</ref> and 4) the Road Ecology Program at the Western Transportation Institute, Montana State University.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wti.montana.edu/ |title=Western Transportation Institute - Western Transportation Institute | Montana State University |website=Wti.montana.edu |date= |accessdate=2017-05-23}}</ref> There are also several important global conferences for road ecology research: 1) Infra-Eco Network Europe (IENE),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iene.info |title=IENE – Infra Eco Network Europe |website=Iene.info |date= |accessdate=2017-05-23}}</ref> which is international, but focused primarily on Europe; 2) International Conference on Ecology and Transportation (ICOET),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icoet.net |title=2017 International Conference on Ecology and Transportation |publisher=ICOET |date= |accessdate=2017-05-23}}</ref> which is also global in scope, but primarily focused on the US; 3) Australasian Network for Ecology & Transportation (ANET),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ecologyandtransport.com/ |title=ANET |website=Ecologyandtransport.com |date= |accessdate=2017-05-23}}</ref> which focuses on the Australasian (sub)continent; and 4) a potential Southern African road ecology conference, being considered by the Endangered Wildlife Trust.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ewt.org.za |title=Endangered Wildlife Trust |website=Ewt.org.za |date= |accessdate=2017-05-23}}</ref>
==Air quality== [[File:Aab Pasadena Highway Los Angeles.jpg|thumb|right|Air pollution along Pasadena Highway in [[Los Angeles]], [[United States]]]] Roads can have both negative and positive effects on air quality.
=== Negative effects === {{Further|Exhaust gas}} [[Air pollution]] from fossil (and some biofuel) powered vehicles can occur wherever vehicles are used and are of particular concern in congested city street conditions and other low speed circumstances. Emissions include [[particulate]] emissions from [[diesel engine]]s, [[NOx#Health effects|NO<sub>''x''</sub>]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.epa.gov/air/urbanair/nox/noxfldr.pdf |title=How nitrogen oxides affect the way we live and breathe |accessdate=2008-12-10 |publisher=Environmental protection agency |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080716063437/http://www.epa.gov/air/urbanair/nox/noxfldr.pdf <!-- Bot retrieved archive --> |archivedate = 2008-07-16}}</ref> [[volatile organic compound]]s,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.epa.gov/air/emissions/voc.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-04-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100514235526/http://www.epa.gov/air/emissions/voc.htm |archivedate=2010-05-14 |df= }}</ref> [[carbon monoxide]]<ref name="Toxicology2002-omaye">{{cite journal|author=Omaye ST.| title=Metabolic modulation of carbon monoxide toxicity|journal=Toxicology|year=2002|pages=139–150|volume=180|issue=2|doi=10.1016/S0300-483X(02)00387-6|pmid=12324190}}</ref> and various other hazardous air pollutants including [[Benzene#Health effects|benzene]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaa.com/motoring_advice/car-buyers-guide/cbg_toxics.html |title=Vehicle exhaust emissions |website=Theaa.com |date=2017-01-11 |accessdate=2017-05-23}}</ref> Concentrations of air pollutants and adverse [[respiratory]] health effects are greater near the road than at some distance away from the road.<ref Name="carbonblack">{{cite web | title = Traffic-related Air Pollution near Busy Roads | work = | publisher = American Journal of Respiratory and Critical Care Medicine Vol 170. pp. 520-526 | year = 2004 | url = http://ajrccm.atsjournals.org/cgi/content/full/170/5/520 | accessdate = }}</ref> [[Road dust]] kicked up by vehicles may trigger [[allergic]] reactions.<ref>[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/1999/11/991130062843.htm "Road Dust - Something To Sneeze About."] ''Science Daily,'' 1999-11-30. [[Sand]] applied to icy roads can be ground up by traffic into fine particulates and contribute to air pollution.</ref> [[Carbon dioxide]] is non-toxic to humans but is a major [[greenhouse gas]] and motor vehicle emissions are an important contributor to the growth of CO<sub>2</sub> concentrations in the atmosphere and therefore to [[global warming]].
=== Positive effects === The construction of new roads which divert traffic from built-up areas can deliver improved air quality to the areas relieved of a significant amount of traffic. The ''Environmental and Social Impact Assessment Study'' carried out for the development of the Tirana Outer Ring Road estimated that it would result in improved air quality in Tirana city center.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ebrd.com/projects/eias/38735.pdf |title=Tirana Outer Ring Road: Environmental and Social Impact Assessment Study |publisher=Bernard Engineers & Brenner Engineers |year=2009 |accessdate=2010-04-27 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
A new section of road being built near [[Hindhead]], UK, to replace a four-mile section of the [[A3 road]], and which includes the new [[Hindhead Tunnel]], is expected by the government to deliver huge environmental benefits to the area including the removal of daily congestion, the elimination of air pollution in Hindhead caused by the congestion, and the removal of an existing road which crosses the environmentally sensitive [[Devil's Punchbowl]] area of outstanding natural beauty. (UTC)<ref>{{cite press release | title = £371 million A3 improvements will go ahead | publisher = [[Department for Transport]] | date = 2006-10-27 | url = http://www.wired-gov.net/wg/wg-news-1.nsf/0/066B5C0DA1399C58802572AB004BDC21?OpenDocument | accessdate = 2011-07-04 }}</ref>
==Hydrology== {{see also|Stormwater}} [[Urban runoff]] from roads and other [[impervious surface]]s is a major source of [[water pollution]].<ref>United States. National Research Council. Washington, DC. [http://www.epa.gov/npdes/pubs/nrc_stormwaterreport.pdf "Urban Stormwater Management in the United States."] October 15, 2008. pp. 5, 110.</ref> [[Rainwater]] and [[snowmelt]] running off of roads tends to pick up [[gasoline]], [[motor oil]], [[heavy metals]], [[waste|trash]] and other pollutants. Road runoff is a major source of [[nickel]], [[copper]], [[zinc]], [[cadmium]], [[lead]] and [[polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon]]s (PAHs), which are created as [[combustion]] byproducts of gasoline and other [[fossil fuel]]s.<ref>{{cite book|title=Stormwater Effects Handbook: A Toolbox for Watershed Managers, Scientists, and Engineers|publisher=CRC/Lewis Publishers|location=New York|year=2001|isbn=0-87371-924-7|url=http://unix.eng.ua.edu/~rpitt/Publications/BooksandReports/Stormwater%20Effects%20Handbook%20by%20%20Burton%20and%20Pitt%20book/MainEDFS_Book.html|author1=G. Allen Burton, Jr. |author2=Robert Pitt }} Chapter 2.</ref>
[[De-icing]] chemicals and sand can run off into roadsides, contaminate [[groundwater]] and pollute [[surface water]]s.<ref>Charles Seawell and Newland Agbenowosi (1998).[http://www.cee.vt.edu/ewr/environmental/teach/gwprimer/roadsalt/roadsalt.html "Effects of Road Deicing Salts on Groundwater Systems."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090521095505/http://www.cee.vt.edu/ewr/environmental/teach/gwprimer/roadsalt/roadsalt.html |date=2009-05-21 }} Virginia Polytechnic Institute, Department of Civil Engineering.</ref> [[Road salt]]s (primarily [[chloride]]s of [[sodium]], [[calcium]] or [[magnesium]]) can be [[toxic]] to sensitive plants and animals.<ref>University of Minnesota (2009). [http://www1.umn.edu/news/news-releases/2009/UR_RELEASE_MIG_5295.html "U of M research finds most road salt is making it into the state's lakes and rivers."] 2009-02-10.</ref> Sand can alter [[stream bed]] environments, causing stress for the plants and animals that live there. Several studies have found a definite difference in physical properties of waters between catchments or hydric systems immediately adjacent to roads compared with those in environments further away from the studied roads.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Waara|first=Sylvia|last2=Färm|first2=Carina|date=May 2008|title=An assessment of the potential toxicity of runoff from an urban roadscape during rain events|journal=Environmental Science and Pollution Research International|volume=15|issue=3|pages=205–210|issn=0944-1344|pmid=18504838}}</ref> De-icing chemicals, salt, chlorides and the nutrients brought by particulate pollution such as [[Nitrogen cycle|nitrogen]] (N) and [[phosphorus]] (P) can trigger [[trophic cascade]]s in adjacent waterways.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Castillo|first=Anakena M.|last2=Sharpe|first2=Diana M. T.|last3=Ghalambor|first3=Cameron K.|last4=León|first4=Luis F. De|date=2018-02-01|title=Exploring the effects of salinization on trophic diversity in freshwater ecosystems: a quantitative review|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10750-017-3403-0|journal=Hydrobiologia|language=en|volume=807|issue=1|pages=1–17|doi=10.1007/s10750-017-3403-0|issn=0018-8158}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hintz|first=William D.|last2=Mattes|first2=Brian M.|last3=Schuler|first3=Matthew S.|last4=Jones|first4=Devin K.|last5=Stoler|first5=Aaron B.|last6=Lind|first6=Lovisa|last7=Relyea|first7=Rick A.|date=2017-04-01|title=Salinization triggers a trophic cascade in experimental freshwater communities with varying food-chain length|url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1002/eap.1487|journal=Ecological Applications|language=en|volume=27|issue=3|pages=833–844|doi=10.1002/eap.1487|issn=1939-5582}}</ref>
===De-icing chemicals=== The chemicals applied to roads along with grit for [[de-ice|de-icing]] are primarily [[Road salt|Salt]] and [[calcium chloride]].<ref name=Ramakrishna>{{cite journal|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11270-005-8265-9?LI=true#page-1|title=Environmental Impact Of Chemical Deicers – A Review |author1=Devikarani M. Ramakrishna |author2=Thiruvenkatachari Viraraghavan |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2005|journal=Water, Air, & Soil Pollution|volume=166|pages=49–63|doi=10.1007/s11270-005-8265-9}}</ref> Other chemicals such as [[urea]] are also used.<ref name=Ramakrishna/> These chemicals leave the road surface either in water runoff or in water spray. Apart from [[Heavy metals|heavy metal]] [[bioaccumulation]]<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Heintzman|first=Rebecca L.|last2=Titus|first2=John E.|last3=Zhu|first3=Weixing|date=2015-02-01|title=Effects of Roadside Deposition on Growth and Pollutant Accumulation by Willow (Salix miyabeana)|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s11270-014-2270-9|journal=Water, Air, & Soil Pollution|language=en|volume=226|issue=2|pages=11|doi=10.1007/s11270-014-2270-9|issn=0049-6979}}</ref> in adjacent plants, vegetation can be damaged by salt as far as {{convert|100|m|yd|abbr=on}} from the road.<ref>{{cite book|title=Impact Of De-Icing Salt On Roadside Vegetation. A Literature Review|author=G. Blomqvist|url=http://trid.trb.org/view.aspx?id=656069|publisher=Swedish National Road and Transport Research Institute (VTI)}}</ref> Studies have found negative effects on [[wood frog]] population dynamics when [[tadpole]]s were raised in presence of most de-icing chemicals, such as decreased tadpole survival rates and modified sex ratios at maturity.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Harless|first=Meagan L.|last2=Huckins|first2=Casey J|last3=Grant|first3=Jacqualine B.|last4=Pypker|first4=Thomas G.|date=2011-07-01|title=Effects of six chemical deicers on larval wood frogs (Rana sylvatica)|url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1002/etc.544|journal=Environmental Toxicology and Chemistry|language=en|volume=30|issue=7|pages=1637–1641|doi=10.1002/etc.544|issn=1552-8618}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lambert|first=Max R.|last2=Stoler|first2=Aaron B.|last3=Smylie|first3=Meredith S.|last4=Relyea|first4=Rick A.|last5=Skelly|first5=David K.|date=2016-11-22|title=Interactive effects of road salt and leaf litter on wood frog sex ratios and sexual size dimorphism|url=http://www.nrcresearchpress.com/doi/10.1139/cjfas-2016-0324|journal=Canadian Journal of Fisheries and Aquatic Sciences|volume=74|issue=2|pages=141–146|doi=10.1139/cjfas-2016-0324|issn=0706-652X}}</ref>
An increased level of chloride in water due to salt application to roads can be widespread in waterways, rather than a local phenomenon of the road edge itself.<ref name="Ramakrishna" />
==Noise== Motor vehicle traffic on roads will generate [[noise]], in a wide range of [[Audio frequency|frequencies]] which can affect both humans and animals.
===Negative effects=== [[Noise pollution]] is a factor of environmental degradation that is often overlooked and typically seen as not having a significant effect, though traffic noise can contribute to numerous disturbances for wildlife. An increasing number of studies have been done on the effects of noise on wildlife. Both the sounds made by motors and the wind over moving vehicle structures, and the ultrasonic vibrations transmitted through the air and ground from vehicle passage can overlap with the frequency ranges and amplitudes used by animals for [[Animal communication|communication]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Francis|first=Clinton D.|last2=Ortega|first2=Catherine P.|last3=Cruz|first3=Alexander|title=Noise Pollution Changes Avian Communities and Species Interactions|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0960982209013281|journal=Current Biology|volume=19|issue=16|pages=1415–1419|doi=10.1016/j.cub.2009.06.052}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shier|first=D.M.|last2=Lea|first2=A.J.|last3=Owen|first3=M.A.|title=Beyond masking: Endangered Stephen’s kangaroo rats respond to traffic noise with footdrumming|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0006320712001504|journal=Biological Conservation|volume=150|issue=1|pages=53–58|doi=10.1016/j.biocon.2012.03.007}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Grade|first=Aaron M.|last2=Sieving|first2=Kathryn E.|date=2016-04-01|title=When the birds go unheard: highway noise disrupts information transfer between bird species|url=http://rsbl.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/12/4/20160113|journal=Biology Letters|language=en|volume=12|issue=4|pages=20160113|doi=10.1098/rsbl.2016.0113|issn=1744-9561|pmid=27095267|pmc=4881358}}</ref>
Several studies revealed that noise can have a negative effect, particularly on birds. Noise from major roads can interrupt or interfere with the calls of song birds, and their instinctive calls associated with mating, communication, migration, and other purposes are hindered by noise from roads. One study did not necessarily directly provide a fatal effect for the tested birds, but the study showed that species abundance declined around major roads due to noise.<ref name="Fahrig">Fahrig, Lenore, and Trina Rytwinski. "Effects Of Roads On Animal Abundance: An Empirical Review And Synthesis."Ecology & Society 14.1 (2009): 1-20. Environment Complete. Web. 25 Sept. 2013.</ref> Noise effects may also modify the behaviour of certain species, such as birds and their feeding behaviours. Birds may spend an increasing amount of time using visual scanning to spot predators as a result of auditory cues and alarm signals from other species being masked by noise pollution. A decreased amount of time spent feeding may lower the mean body weight of birds living near roads, which directly affects their survival rates in a negative fashion.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=HABIB|first=LUCAS|last2=BAYNE|first2=ERIN M.|last3=BOUTIN|first3=STAN|date=2007-02-01|title=Chronic industrial noise affects pairing success and age structure of ovenbirds Seiurus aurocapilla|url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1111/j.1365-2664.2006.01234.x|journal=Journal of Applied Ecology|language=en|volume=44|issue=1|pages=176–184|doi=10.1111/j.1365-2664.2006.01234.x|issn=1365-2664}}</ref>
Road noise can be a nuisance if it impinges on population centres, especially for roads at higher operating speeds, near intersections and on uphill sections. [[Noise health effects]] can be expected in such locations from road systems used by large numbers of motor vehicles. [[Noise mitigation]] strategies exist to reduce sound levels at nearby sensitive receptors. The idea that road design could be influenced by [[acoustical engineering]] considerations first arose about 1973.{{Citation needed|date=November 2009}}
[[Speed bumps]], which are usually deployed in built-up areas, can increase [[noise pollution]]. This is especially the case if large vehicles use the road and particularly at night.
===Positive effects=== New roads can divert traffic away from population centres thus relieving the [[noise pollution]]. A new road scheme planned in [[Shropshire]], UK promises to reduce traffic noise in [[Shrewsbury]] town centre.<ref name=shrop>{{cite web |url=http://www.shropshire.gov.uk/shropshire/hwmaint.nsf/open/B84F3EBBC9BC5680802576D6004FC025 |title=FAQs for the North West Relief Road |year=2010 |publisher=Shropshire Council |accessdate=2010-05-14}}</ref>
==Effects on wildlife== === Habitat fragmentation === {{main|Barrier effect}} [[File:Indian Giant Squirrel Ratufa indica malabar giant squirrel roadkill anaimalai hills.jpg|thumb|220x220px|[[Indian giant squirrel]], a [[Arboreal animal|tree dweller]], killed on a road that has disrupted the rainforest canopy]] Roads can act as barriers or filters to animal movement and lead to [[habitat fragmentation]].<ref name=RMEE> {{cite journal |last1= Forman |first1= R.T.T. |last2= Alexander |first2= L.E. |year= 1998 |title= Roads and their major ecological effects |journal= Annual Review of Ecology and Systematics |publisher= |volume= 29 |issue= |pages= 207–31 |url= http://pracownia.org.pl/pliki/roads_and_their_major_ecological_effects.pdf |doi= 10.1146/annurev.ecolsys.29.1.207}}</ref> Many species will not cross the open space created by a road due to the threat of [[predation]]<ref name=PRI>{{cite book |title= A Primer of Conservation Biology (3rd ed) |last= Primack |first= R.B. |year= 2004 |publisher= Sinauer Associates, Inc. |location= Massachusetts, U.S.A. |isbn= 0-87893-728-5 |pages=84–89 }}</ref> and roads also cause increased animal mortality from traffic.<ref name=MELES>{{cite journal |last1= Philip Clarke |first1= G. |last2= White |first2= P.C.L. |last3= Harris |first3= S |year= 1998 |title= Effects of roads on badger Meles meles populations in south-west England |journal= Biological Conservation |publisher= Elsevier Ltd. |volume= 86 |issue= 2 |pages= 117–124 |url= http://pracownia.org.pl/pliki/roads_and_their_major_ecological_effects.pdf |doi= 10.1016/S0006-3207(98)00018-4}}</ref> This barrier effect can prevent species from [[Animal migration|migrating]] and recolonising areas where the species has gone locally [[extinct]] as well as restricting access to seasonally available or widely scattered resources.<ref name=PRI/>
Habitat fragmentation may also divide large continuous populations into smaller more isolated populations.<ref name=RMEE/> These smaller populations are more vulnerable to [[genetic drift]], [[inbreeding depression]] and an increased risk of population decline and extinction.<ref name=PRI/> Whether or not this effect is observed depends greatly on the size and mobility of the species in question and the spatial scale at which the fragmetation occurs.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=KELLER|first=I.|last2=NENTWIG|first2=W.|last3=LARGIADÈR|first3=C. R.|date=2004-10-01|title=Recent habitat fragmentation due to roads can lead to significant genetic differentiation in an abundant flightless ground beetle|url=http://doi.wiley.com/10.1111/j.1365-294X.2004.02310.x|journal=Molecular Ecology|language=en|volume=13|issue=10|pages=2983–2994|doi=10.1111/j.1365-294x.2004.02310.x|issn=1365-294X}}</ref> Fragmentation does not affect all species in the same way.
The presence of roads also decreases the amount of habitat accessible to species. This is to say that it decreases the amount of usable habitat available to organisms without crossing a road. That being said, whether a habitat on the other side of the road becomes inaccessible to an organism or not varies between species. Roads are a permeable barrier to some organisms and impermeable to others.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Eigenbrod|first=Felix|last2=Hecnar|first2=Stephen J.|last3=Fahrig|first3=Lenore|date=2008-02-01|title=Accessible habitat: an improved measure of the effects of habitat loss and roads on wildlife populations|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10980-007-9174-7|journal=Landscape Ecology|language=en|volume=23|issue=2|pages=159–168|doi=10.1007/s10980-007-9174-7|issn=0921-2973}}</ref>
===Amphibians and reptiles=== [[Image:Common-snapping-turtle.jpg|thumb|right|[[Common snapping turtle|Snapping turtle]] (''Chelydra serpentina'') crossing a road]] Roads can be particularly hazardous to populations of amphibians and reptiles that migrate to vernal pools,<ref>Keddy, P.A. 2010. Wetland Ecology: Principles and Conservation (2nd edition). Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK. 497 p.</ref> or to the gravel on road verges that several species try to use as nest sites.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Aresco | first1 = M. | doi = 10.1016/j.biocon.2004.10.006 | title = The effect of sex-specific terrestrial movements and roads on the sex ratio of freshwater turtles | journal = Biological Conservation | volume = 123 | pages = 37–44 | year = 2005 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> Reptiles’ instinctive activities can lead them towards roads and lead to an increase in mortality rates: snakes, for example, may use roads as a source of heat for thermoregulation. Also some turtles have been noted to lay their eggs on road shoulders. Migratory patterns from season to season can also bring frogs and snakes into contact with roads and lead to an increase in their mortality rates.<ref name=Fahrig/>
===Birds=== The traffic load near large cities may show dramatic cyclical changes induced by weekend tourism, and this could induce cyclical changes in the activity patterns of birds.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Bautista |first1=L.M. |last2=García |first2=J.T.|last3=Calmaestra |first3=R.G. |last4=Palacín |first4=C.|last5=Martín |first5=C.A. |last6=Morales |first6=M.B.|last7=Bonal |first7=R.|last8=Viñuela |first8=J. |year=2004|title=Effect of weekend road traffic on the use of space by raptors |journal=Conservation Biology |volume=18 |pages=725–732 |url=https://digital.csic.es/handle/10261/43806 |doi=10.1111/j.1523-1739.2004.00499.x}}</ref> Road implantation may also lead birds to avoid certain sites, as they are seen as being less habitable (because of increases in noise and chemical pollution). Certain bird populations may then become confined into smaller habitable sites, leading to an increase in possibility of extinction caused by illness or habitat perturbation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Pinto|first=Márcia|last2=Rocha|first2=Pedro|last3=Moreira|first3=Francisco|title=Long-term trends in great bustard (Otis tarda) populations in Portugal suggest concentration in single high quality area|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S000632070500073X|journal=Biological Conservation|volume=124|issue=3|pages=415–423|doi=10.1016/j.biocon.2005.01.047}}</ref>
===Facilitation of poaching of flora and fauna=== {{Main| Bush meat|Wildlife trade|Illegal logging}} Roads that run through forests that house edible animals may encourage or facilitate [[poaching]]. Especially in poor areas, the construction of roads has promoted not only poaching for personal consumption but also for sale (for consumption or as a pet) to third parties.
Similarly, the construction of roads in forested areas has also promoted illegal logging as it becomes easier for illegal loggers to transport the wood.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.illegal-logging.info/content/roads-are-ruining-rainforests |title=Roads are ruining the rainforests | Illegal Logging Portal |website=Illegal-logging.info |date= |accessdate=2017-05-23}}</ref>
==Mitigation efforts== ===Awareness=== Awareness needs to be spread among drivers particularly those driving on forest road on maintaining speed limits and being vigilant. [[Environment Conservation Group]] had initiated an awareness drive named PATH an acronym for Provide Animals safe Transit on Highways<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sanctuaryasia.com/magazines/conservation/10297-driven-to-protect-a-journey-across-india-to-document-wild-roadkills.html |title=Driven To Protect – A Journey Across India To Document Wild Roadkills |website=Sanctuaryasia.com |date= |accessdate=2017-05-23}}</ref> covering more than 17,000 km in India to highlighting the importance of safe driving on forest roads.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-in-school/stop-the-animals-are-crossing/article8029760.ece|title=Stop! The animals are crossing|author=K. Jeshi|newspaper=[[The Hindu]]|access-date=7 April 2016}}</ref>
===Road permeability=== [[Wildlife crossings]] that allow [[animal]]s to safely cross human-made barriers such as roads, are intended not only to reduce roadkill, but ideally to provide connectivity of habitat areas, combating [[habitat fragmentation]].<ref name=Forman/> Wildlife crossings may include: [[Tunnel|underpass tunnels]], [[viaduct]]s, and [[overpass]]es.
===Habitat construction and planting=== In Washington County, North Carolina, along Highway 64, a study was conducted to analyze the effects of wildlife underpasses on the local wildlife. Three wildlife underpasses were built with fencing around the highway in the study zones. The study showed that deer used the underpasses the most and made up 93% of all crossings. Mortality rates were calculated and showed that the numbers of deaths were lower near underpasses. This cannot be said about all animals. Some have smaller home ranges so they were not inclined to travel to underpasses to cross the road. Underpass would most likely benefit larger mammals such as bears, deer, and cougars. Underpasses were seen to lower mortality rates and increase local species ability to adapt to a habitat along a major road.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=McCollister, Matthew F. |author2=Frank T. Van Manen |lastauthoramp=yes |year=2010|title=Effectiveness of Wildlife Underpasses and Fencing to Reduce Wildlife-Vehicle Collisions|journal=Journal of Wildlife Management|volume=74|issue=8|pages=1722–1731|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.2193/2009-535|doi=10.2193/2009-535}}</ref>
===Recycling=== Materials removed from a road can be reused in construction within the same project<ref name=SCS> {{cite journal |last1= Sianipar |first1= C.P.M. |last2= Dowaki |first2= K. |year= 2014 |title= Eco-burden in pavement maintenance: Effects from excess traffic growth and overload |journal= Sustainable Cities and Society |publisher= |volume= 12 |issue= |pages= 31–45 |url= http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S2210670714000043 |doi= 10.1016/j.scs.2014.01.002}}</ref> or in other locations. Road construction can also use waste materials from other industries.
Asphalt pavement is one of the most recycled materials in the United States. It is estimated that over 80% of asphalt pavement removed from roadways is reused as [[construction aggregate]]. It can be mixed into new pavement or used as a subbase or fill material. Similarly, concrete from road or building demolition can be an excellent source of aggregate.<ref name=waste>{{cite book |url=https://www.fhwa.dot.gov/publications/research/infrastructure/structures/97148/ |title=User Guidelines for Waste and Byproduct Materials in Pavement Construction |publisher=Federal Highway Administration |date= 2012-04-23 }}</ref>
Common examples of waste products used in road building include coal [[fly ash]] (used to make concrete stronger), asphalt shingles and shredded [[waste tire|tire]]s (used in asphalt pavement), ground glass and steel mill [[slag]] (used as aggregates).<ref name=waste/>
In 2012, US asphalt plants used an estimated 68.3 million tons of reclaimed asphalt pavement, 1.86 million tons of recycled asphalt shingles, and over 1 million tons of other recycled materials to produce new asphalt.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cdrecycler.com/napa-survey-recycled-asphalt.aspsx |title=Survey finds growth in recycled materials for asphalt |work=Construction and Demolition Recycling |date=February 5, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223141734/http://www.cdrecycler.com/napa-survey-recycled-asphalt.aspsx |archivedate=February 23, 2014 |df= }}</ref>
==See also== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} * [[Acoustic ecology]] * [[Anthropocene]] * [[Congestion pricing]] * [[Car#Environmental impact|Environmental impact of cars]] * [[Environmental impact of transport]] * [[Truck#Environmental impact|Environmental impact of trucks]] * [[Habitat fragmentation]] * [[Low-emission zone]] * [[Motor vehicle emissions]] * [[Population fragmentation]] * [[Railroad ecology]] * [[Rubberized asphalt]] * [[Synanthrope]] * [[Transport and the environment#Mitigation of environmental impact|Transport and the environment]] * [[Wildlife crossing]] {{div col end}}
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
{{Environmental science}} {{Portal bar|Ecology|Roads|Transport}}

revision.text:
{{For|the stage play|Seascape (play)}} [[File:The Wave - Pierre-Auguste Renoir - Google Cultural Institute.jpg|thumbnail|''The Wave'' by [[Pierre-Auguste Renoir]] ]]
[[Image:Winslow Homer Summer Squall.jpg|thumb|140px|''Summer Squall'', 1904. A seascape by [[Winslow Homer]].]]
A '''seascape''' is a [[photograph]], [[painting]], or other [[work of art]] which depicts the [[sea]], in other words an example of [[marine art]]. The word originated as a formation from [[landscape]], which was first used of images of land in art. By a similar development, "seascape" has also come to mean actual views of the sea itself, and to be applied in [[urban planning|planning contexts]] to geographical locations possessing a good view of the sea.
==Planning use== [[File:Clifton Beach 5.jpg|thumb|left|140px|A seascape photograph at [[Clifton Beach, Tasmania|Clifton Beach]], [[South Arm, Tasmania|South Arm]], [[Tasmania]], Australia]]
In the UK a seascape is defined in planning and land use contexts as a combination of adjacent land, [[coastline]] and [[sea]] within an area, defined by a mix of land-sea inter-visibility and coastal landscape character assessment, with major headlands forming division points between one seascape area and the next. This approach to coastal [[landscape planning]] was developed jointly by Government environmental bodies in [[Wales]] (UK) and [[Ireland]] in 2000 to assist spatial planning for (at that time new) [[offshore wind farm]] developments. The resulting "Guide to best practice in seascape assessment <ref>[http://oar.marine.ie/bitstream/10793/553/1/INTERREG%205%20Guide%20to%20Best%20Practice%20in%20Seascape%20Assessment.pdf Guide to the Best Practice in Seascape Assessment]</ref>", (Marine Institute, Ireland, 2001), have since been adapted and applied in [[Scotland]] <ref>[http://www.snh.gov.uk/pubs/detail.asp?id=419]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}(Scottish Natural Heritage, UK, 2004) and in [[England]] {{cite web |url=http://www.berr.gov.uk/files/file22852.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2010-03-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=http://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/20100304133237/http%3A//www.berr.gov.uk/files/file22852.pdf |archivedate=2010-03-04 |df= }}(Defra, 2005)</ref> and [[Wales]]<ref>[https://www.webarchive.org.uk/wayback/archive/20100405015051/http://www.ccw.gov.uk/landscape--wildlife/protecting-our-landscape/assessing-seascapes/seascape-assessment.aspx] (Countryside Council for Wales, 2009)</ref> for guidance to offshore wind farm developers and for carrying out spatial planning assessments.
Meanwhile, the word has also been adopted in England <ref>[http://www.english-heritage.org.uk/server/show/nav.8684](English Heritage, 2008)</ref> referring to the historic and archaeological character areas of the sea - a different but complementary methodological approach encompassing what lies beneath the sea surface. This use of the word departs from the focus on scenery and visual perception, relying instead just on cognitive perception (what lies beneath the sea surface is out of sight to most of us).
The [[Welsh language]] already distinguishes between 'Morluniau' (seascape in the traditional sense of a [[picture]], [[Perspective (visual)|view]] or [[painting]]) and 'Morweddau' (seascape as a distinct, geographical area exhibiting particular characteristics and qualities). There is no such distinction in the English language.
== References == {{Commons category|Seascapes}} {{portal|Environment}} <references />
[[Category:Land use]] [[Category:Landscape]] [[Category:Water]]

{{advert|date=April 2014}}
'''SPARK''' is an award winning international [[architecture]] and [[urban design]] practice based in [[Beijing]], [[London]], [[Singapore]] and [[Shanghai]]. Since 2001 the studio was responsible for designing a wide range of projects from complex multi-phase mixed use buildings to small scale special urban infill projects.
== Practice ==
'''Spark''' is an [[architectural firm]], focused on [[architecture]], [[urban design]], [[landscape architecture]] and [[interior design]]. Founded in 2008, the practice has a team of over 100 employees spanning 16 nationalities and three continents. SPARK’s projects include the rejuvenated Clarke Quay in [[Singapore]], the Shanghai International Cruise Terminal, Starhill Gallery Kuala Lumpur and the Raffles City projects in Ningbo and [[Beijing]].
== Partners ==
* Stephen Pimbley * Wenhui Lim
== Projects ==
=== Completed ===
* Faifah Learning Center, Bangkok, Thailand, Completed 2012.<ref name="Faifah Learning Center" /> * Forte Nanshan, China, Completed 2011.<ref name="Forte Nanshan" /> * Starhill Gallery, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, Completed 2011.<ref name="Starhill Gallery" /> * [[Clarke Quay]], Singapore, Completed 2011.<ref name="Clarke Quay" /> * One Mont Kiara, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, Completed 2010.<ref name="One Mont Kiara" /> * Raffles City Beijing, China, Completed 2009.<ref name="Raffles City Beijing" /> * Semarang Paragon City, Semarang, Java, Indonesia, Completed 2009 * Shanghai International Cruise Terminal, China, Completed 2010.<ref name="Shanghai International Cruise Terminal" />
=== Concept ===
* Wanda Wuhan Grand Hotel, Wuhan, China, 2012 * Hangzhou Yunhe, Hangzhou, China, 2011 * CITS Travel City, Sanya, China, 2010 * Vanke Super City, Zhongshan, China, 2010 * Vanke Super City, Zhongshan, China, 2010 * Shanghai Kiss, Shanghai, China, 2004
== References == {{Reflist| refs= <ref name="Faifah Learning Center">Project Published: 2012 June Interior Design. 2012 May, Cubes Magazine.</ref> <ref name="Forte Nanshan">Project Published: 2012 June, Architecture & Technology . 2012 June, Urbanism & Architecture. 2012 June, Area. 2012 April, Tatler. 2012 April, Interior Designer. 2012 April, id+c. 2012 April, BOB. 2012 April, Architecture & Details.</ref> <ref name="Starhill Gallery">Project Published: 2012 April, Trends commercial Design Magazine. 2012 January, Architecture Malaysia Magazine. 2011 November, Indonesia Design Magazine. 2011 October, Surface Asia Magazine. 2011 October, d+a_Magazine. 2011 July, Space Magazine.</ref> <ref name="Clarke Quay">Project Published: 2010 June, Soft Living Magazine. 2010 May,Taiwan Architect Magazine.</ref> <ref name="One Mont Kiara">Project Published: 2011 April, Architecture Malaysia Magazine. 2011 March, IQD Inside Quality Design Magazine. 2011 January / Blueprint Asia Magazine. 2011 January, AIT Magazine.</ref> <ref name="Raffles City Beijing">Project Published: 2009 September, Taiwan Architect Magazine.</ref> <ref name="Shanghai International Cruise Terminal">Project Published: 2012 February, Wallpaper Thailand Magazine. 2011 July, Trends commercial Design Magazine. 2010 July, B1 Magazine. 2010 June, Taiwan Architect Magazine. 2010 June, Perspective Magazine. 2010 June, FuturArc Magazine. 2010 May, RFP Magazine.</ref> }}

'''Stockholm City Centre''' (''Stockholms innerstad'', ''Innerstaden'', ''Inre staden'') is the [[city centre]]{{citation needed|date=July 2018}} of [[Stockholm]] in [[Sweden]]. The entire city of Stockholm is also the centre of the [[Metropolitan Stockholm|Stockholm Metropolitan Area]]. Since 2007, Stockholm City Centre is organized into four ''stadsdelsområden'' (sometimes translated to [[Boroughs of Stockholm|boroughs]]): [[Kungsholmen (borough)|Kungsholmen]], [[Södermalm]], [[Norrmalm]] and [[Östermalm]].City of Stockholm: [http://stockholm.se/-/English/Stockholm-by-districts/ "Stockholm by districts"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081218065732/http://stockholm.se/-/English/Stockholm-by-districts/ |date=December 18, 2008 }} Before 2007, Stockholm City Centre was organized into five boroughs: [[Katarina-Sofia borough]], [[Kungsholmen borough]], [[Maria-Gamla stan borough]], [[Norrmalm borough]] and [[Östermalm borough]]. The border between the historical [[Provinces of Sweden|provinces]] of [[Södermanland]] and [[Uppland]] splits Stockholm City Centre in two parts. 179,185 people live on an area of 28.05 km² in the northern (Uppland) part, which gives a density of 6,388.06/km².{{citation needed|date=July 2018}} The same data for the southern (Södermanland) part is 103,646 people on 7.44 km², giving a density of 13,930.91/km².{{citation needed|date=July 2018}} This border is purely historical and has no administrative significance whatsoever. {{wide image|Stockholm stadshuset.jpg|1800px|Stockholm City Centre}} ==Districts== {| class="wikitable sortable" border="1" |+ Sortable table |-bgcolor=#dddddd ! District !! Area ([[hectare|ha]]){{cite web|title=Area and population density by City district |publisher=Stockholms stads utrednings- och statistikkontor AB |url=http://www.usk.stockholm.se/arsbok/b039.htm |date=2007-12-31 |accessdate=2009-04-07 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110720133832/http://www.usk.stockholm.se/arsbok/b039.htm |archivedate=July 20, 2011 }} !! [[image:Tavoliere.jpg|thumb|300px|The Tavoliere seen from the [[Gargano]] promontory.]] The '''Tavoliere delle Puglie''' ([[Italian language|Italian]]: "Table of the Apulias", {{IPA-it|tavoˈljɛːre delle ˈpuʎʎe|pron}}) is a [[plain]] in northern [[Apulia]], southern Italy, occupying nearly a half of the [[Capitanata]] traditional region. It covers a surface of c. 3,000 km², once constituting a sea bottom: it is bounded by the [[Monti Dauni|Daunian Pre-Apennines]] on the West, the [[Gargano Promontory]] and the [[Adriatic Sea]] on the East, by the [[Fortore]] river on the north, and the [[Ofanto]] river on the south. It is the largest Italian plain after the [[Pianura Padana]].
The name ''Tavoliere'' derives from the [[Latin language|Latin]] term ''Tabulae censuariae'', tables on which the [[ancient Rome|Romans]] classified the areas devoted to sheep farming or agriculture.
In winter the plain is sometimes subject to [[flood]]s by the Ofanto and the Fortore, while in summer [[drought]] is frequent.
The main centres, from north to south, are [[San Severo]], [[Lucera (FG)|Lucera]], [[Foggia]] and [[Cerignola]].
==History== Neolithic farmers living in Tavoliere over 7000 years ago practiced [[Excarnation|ritual defleshing of the dead]]. Light cut marks on the bones suggest the bones were defleshed up to a year after death. They deposited the bones in Scaloria Cave. The human bones were mixed with animal bones, broken pottery and stone tools.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://news.sciencemag.org/archaeology/2015/03/stone-age-italians-defleshed-their-dead |title=Stone-age Italians defleshed their dead |last1=Shaw |first1=Garry |last2= |first2= |date=27 March 2015 |website=[[Science (journal)|Science]] |publisher=[[American Association for the Advancement of Science|AAAS]] |access-date=27 March 2015}}</ref>
During the [[Middle Ages]] the old practices of agriculture and fluvial regulation were lost, the plain being mostly devoted to sheep farming which, using apposite cattle-tracks, reached the Apennines' pasture lands through the Tavoliere. The lands was most marshy and unhealthy.
After extensive works of drainage, the plain is now highly cultivated. Crops include [[wheat]], [[beet]], [[tomato]], especially in the area of [[Foggia]], while also spread are cultivations of [[olive]]s and [[grapes]], which produce quality oils and wines.
==Communes== The ''[[comune|comuni]]'' in the Tavoliere delle Puglie are:
[[Ascoli Satriano]], Alberona, Apricena [[Biccari]]; [[Bovino (FG)|Bovino]], [[Candela (FG)|Candela]], [[Carapelle (FG)|Carapelle]], [[Casalvecchio di Puglia]], [[Castelluccio dei Sauri]], [[Castelnuovo della Daunia]], [[Cerignola]], [[Chieuti]], [[Deliceto]], [[Foggia]], [[Lucera]], [[Manfredonia]], [[Margherita di Savoia (FG)|Margherita di Savoia]], [[Ordona]] (''Herdonia''[http://www.arcadria.eu/immagini/foto/Adriatica/pannelli/ORDONA.jpg]), [[Orta Nova]], [[Poggio Imperiale]], [[San Ferdinando di Puglia]], [[San Paolo di Civitate]], [[San Severo]], [[Serracapriola]], [[Stornara]], [[Stornarella]], [[Torremaggiore]], [[Trinitapoli]], [[Troia (FG)|Troia]], [[Volturino]], [[Zapponeta]].

{{forms of government}} A '''thalassocracy''' (from [[Classical Greek]] {{lang|grc|θάλασσα}} (''thalassa''), meaning "sea", and {{lang|grc|κρατεῖν}} (''kratein''), meaning "power", giving [[Koine Greek]] {{lang|grc|θαλασσοκρατία}} (''thalassokratia''), "sea power") is a state with primarily maritime realms, an [[empire]] at sea (such as the [[Phoenicia]]n network of merchant cities) or a seaborne empire.<ref> {{cite book | last1 = Alpers | first1 = Edward A. | title = The Indian Ocean in World History | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=BXNBAQAAQBAJ | series = New Oxford World History | publisher = Oxford University Press | publication-date = 2013 | page = 80 | isbn = 9780199929948 | accessdate = 2016-02-06 | quote = Portugal's was in every sense a seaborne empire or thalassocracy. }} </ref> Traditional thalassocracies seldom dominate interiors, even in their home territories: Phoenician [[Tyre (Lebanon)|Tyre]], [[Sidon]], and [[Ancient Carthage|Carthage]], or [[Srivijaya]] and [[Majapahit]] in [[Southeast Asia]]. One can distinguish this traditional sense of ''thalassocracy'' from an "empire", where the state's territories, though possibly linked principally or solely by the [[sea lane]]s, generally extend into mainland interiors: the [[Bruneian Empire]] (1368–1888) in Asia.<ref>{{cite book|author1= P. M. Holt|author2= Ann K. S. Lambton|author3= Bernard Lewis|title= The Cambridge History of Islam |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=y99jTbxNbSAC&pg=PA129|date= 21 April 1977|publisher= Cambridge University Press|isbn= 978-0-521-29137-8|pages= 129–}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author1= Barbara Watson Andaya|author2= Leonard Y. Andaya|title= A History of Early Modern Southeast Asia, 1400–1830|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=0Rh2BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA159|date= 19 February 2015|publisher= Cambridge University Press|isbn= 978-0-521-88992-6|pages= 159–}}</ref> Compare to ''[[tellurocracy]]'' "land-based hegemony".<ref> {{cite book | editor1-last = Lukic | editor1-first = Rénéo | editor2-last = Brint | editor2-first = Michael | title = Culture, politics, and nationalism in the age of globalization | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=swKFAAAAMAAJ | publisher = Ashgate | publication-date = 2001 | page = 103 | isbn = 9780754614364 | accessdate = 2015-10-12 | quote = [[Aleksandr Dugin|Dugin]] defines 'thalassocracy' as 'power exercised thanks to the sea,' opposed to 'tellurocracy' or 'power exercised thanks to the land' [...]. The 'thalassocracy' here is the United States and its allies; the 'tellurocracy' is Eurasia. }} </ref>
The term ''thalassocracy'' can also simply refer to [[command of the sea|naval supremacy]], in either military or commercial senses of the word ''supremacy''. The [[Ancient Greeks]] first used the word ''thalassocracy'' to describe the government of the [[Minoan civilization]], whose power depended on its navy.<ref> D. Abulafia, "Thalassocracies", in P. Horden – S. Kinoshita (eds.), ''A Companion to Mediterranean History'', Oxford, 2014, pp. 139–153, here 139–140. </ref> [[Herodotus]] distinguishes sea-power from land-power and spoke of the need to counter the Phoenician thalassocracy by developing a Greek "empire of the sea".<ref> A. Momigliano, "Sea-Power in Greek Thought", The Classical Review, May 1944, 1–7.</ref>
==Examples== [[Image:PhoenicianTrade.png|thumb|left|The Phoenician trade routes in the Mediterranean.]]
There are many ancient examples besides those mentioned above, such as the [[Delian League]]. Aside from this example, which was an empire based primarily on naval power and control of waterways and not on any land possessions, the [[Middle Ages]] saw its fair share of thalassocracies, often land-based empires which controlled the sea. Among the most famous is the [[Republic of Venice]], conventionally divided in the fifteenth century into the ''[[Dogado]]'' of Venice and the Lagoon, the ''[[Domini di Terraferma|Stato di Terraferma]]'' of Venetian holdings in northern Italy, and the ''[[Stato da Màr]]'' of the Venetian outlands bound by the sea: {{quote|This was a scattered empire, reminiscent, though on a very different scale, of the [[Portuguese empire|Portuguese]] and later the [[Dutch East Indies|Dutch empires]] in the Indian Ocean, a trading-post empire forming a long [[Capitalism|capitalist]] antenna; an empire 'on the Phoenician model', to use a more ancient parallel.<ref>[[Fernand Braudel]], ''The Perspective of the World'', vol. III of ''Civilization and Capitalism'' (Harper & Row) 1984:119.</ref>}}
In 7th to 15th century [[Maritime Southeast Asia]], the thalassocracies of [[Srivijaya]] and [[Majapahit]] controlled the sea lanes in Southeast Asia and exploited the spice trade of the [[Maluku islands|Spice Islands]], as well as maritime trade routes between [[India]] and [[China]].
Nearly contemporaneous, the [[Republic of Ragusa]] can be seen as a "thalassocracy", a competitor to Venice.
The [[Early Middle Ages]] ({{c.}} 500 – 1000 AD) saw many of the coastal cities of the [[Mezzogiorno]] develop into minor thalassocracies whose chief powers lay in their ports and their ability to sail navies to defend friendly coasts and ravage enemy ones. These include the variously Greek and [[Lombards|Lombard]] duchies of [[Duchy of Gaeta|Gaeta]], [[Duchy of Naples|Naples]], [[Principality of Salerno|Salerno]] and [[Duchy of Amalfi|Amalfi]]. Later, northern Italy developed its own trade empires based on [[Pisa]] and especially the powerful [[Republic of Genoa]], that rivaled with [[Venice]] (these three, along with Amalfi, were to be called the ''[[Repubbliche marinare]]'', i.e. Maritime Republics).
It was with the modern age, the [[Age of Exploration]], that some of the most remarkable thalassocracies emerged. Anchored in their European territories, several nations established colonial empires held together by naval supremacy. First among them was the [[Portuguese Empire]], followed soon by the [[Spanish Empire]], which was challenged by the [[Dutch Empire]], itself replaced on the high seas by the [[British Empire]], whose landed possessions were immense and held together by the greatest navy of its time. With naval arms races (especially between [[German Empire|Germany]] and [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland|Britain]]) and the end of colonialism and the granting of independence to these colonies, European thalassocracies, which had controlled the world's oceans for centuries, ceased to be.
